talk.start.para: âLast night in this place I began to relate a story about the collapse of the former Soviet Union. I was driven to it after listening to contributions to this debate by members opposite, particularly after the member for Charlton. It reminded me of an interesting parallel but I was cut off by the time clock just as I got to the punchline, so here we go again.

speech.para: In 1991 Mikhail Gorbachev, the then Soviet Premier, left Moscow for a briefâso he intendedâholiday in the Crimea. At the time, he was presiding over the collapse of the former Soviet Union. It was in a mass of its own contradictions and outrages. On 18 August soldiers and government agents, acting on behalf of a conspiracy known as the `Gang of Eight', arrested Gorbachev as the first stage of a neo-communist coup. Of course, that coup was doomed to fail. In fact, the attempted coup hastened the collapse of the communist state, passing power from the hands of a reluctant reformer to those who represented a new Russian democracy. The then US President, George Bush Sr, made perhaps the finest assessment of the coup, its failure and its aftermath. He said:

quote.para: You can't put democracy and freedom back into a box.

speech.para: No, you cannot. Freedom has her own battalionsâI have a budget theme happening here. Freedom has a way of bringing tyrants to heel and, as Douglas MacArthur said, `Whether in chains or in laurels, liberty knows nothing but victories.' That is a lesson that the opposition and their trade union masters are yet to learn. They are desperately trying to stuff workplace freedom and democracy back into a box. At every turn, they have tried to quash the freedom of association and they have sought to thwart the free association of non-union workers. Labor is desperately trying to push the toothpasteâ the workplace freedoms that our workers now enjoyâback into the tube. You just cannot do itâyou can try, but it is very messy.

Perhaps the most insidious weapon has been the compulsory union fee or the bargaining agent's fee. It is a fee designed to penalise non-union workers and force them to bear the cost of negotiations entered into by trade unions of which they are not a member. In a number of cases, the fees demanded have been set at $500âabove and beyond the level of annual union dues. As the minister noted in his second reading speech, these fees are, by their character, premeditated in their coercive intent.

In June last year, I spoke on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2001. That bill was the forerunner of this legislation and lapsed in the Senate with the calling of the 2001 federal election. In my speech on that bill, I applauded the response of the Western Australian Labor government to those fees, for the Premier was quick to condemn the Western Australian branch of the Australian Nursing Federation when it threatened to apply a $400 fee to non-union nurses in 2001. At the time, Premier Gallop described that threat as a `red herring' and `not desirable'. But, in the nine months since June 2001, Western Australians have had the opportunity to witness an emboldening of the trade unions in our state. In days past, we have seen union thugs block the streets in an attempt to intimidate the royal commission into the building industry that has been duly convened by the Commonwealth.

We have heard some appalling evidence in that royal commissionâevidence that, in September 1999, the CFMEU closed down the Westfield Carousel site in Perth, called a meeting of all workers on the site, closed all exits to prevent workers from leaving and then interrogated all workers as to whether or not they were union members. They were then `encouraged' to join on the spot. I guess it is pretty hard to resist if you want to be allowed out to go home for the evening. Then we heard about an official from the CFMEU who actually said on oath that he would shut down a work site if he found non-union members working there and that he had made a successful threat in January at a demolition site at the Western Australian cricket ground, at the WACA. He was asked if such action was appropriate, and Mr Joe McDonald replied:

quote.para: I think it's all in a day's work for a militant union official.

speech.para: Indeed! Then we heard the evidence of companies admitting to paying illegal strike pay on Perth building sites to prevent the trouble the union threatened on non-union work sites. In the past months, we have seen the proliferation of `no ticket, no start' signs and the violent disruption and picketing of non-union work sites in Perth, as well as the escalation of demarcation disputes. These developments have been aided and abetted by the state government, with union leaders egged on by Labor's amendments to Western Australia's industrial relations laws. But I hope, nonetheless, that the Premier has not lost his expressed contempt for bargaining fees and that he will both take a stand against those fees being introduced into Western Australia and support the passage of this bill through the federal parliament by communicating his stance to his federal colleagues.

talk.start.para: âDon't hold your breath.

âI will; I have some hope that the Premier will continue to express contempt for these bargaining fees. It is worthwhile to revisit what this bill will actually do. It will prevent collective agreements certified under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 from containing provisions that would require non-association members to pay bargaining service fees to an associationâa trade union or an employer organisationâ that is party to the agreement. It will also prohibit any conduct designed to force the payment of such fees, whether that conduct takes the form of discriminatory behaviour towards people who refuse to pay a bargaining fee or the encouragement of discriminatory or coercive behaviour or demands by an industrial association for such a bargaining fee. The amendments will deal with the hundreds of federal certified agreements into which compulsory union fee clauses have already been inserted.

speech.para: I do not wish to revisit at length the arguments for this reform, but I shall note the particular inadequacy of the principal argument utilised by opponents of this bill, and that is the question of the free rider problem: are these fees not simply a form of user-pays? Last year I quoted the riposte of Mark Paterson from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry to this false argument. He said:

quote.para: ... unions negotiate agreements on behalf of their members, and have a clear interest in applying the outcome to non-members to ensure that their members are not undercut by other employees. This has been the traditional approach of unions to awards, and they are now using the same technique with agreements. In short, they act to prevent competition.

speech.para: So, far from being a free rider problem, there is an absolute opposition on the part of organised labour in this country to the differential remuneration of union and non-union workers. As the minister noted in his second reading speech on this bill:

quote.para: `User-pays' involves an exchange that is freely entered into by willing and properly informed parties.

speech.para: What this legislation does is oblige industrial organisations to meet the same standards we demand of businesses, which are prevented from demanding payment for unrequested services by fair trading laws. That is an obligation that ought to be observed by union officials. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: â The Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2002 is an interesting bill, when you look at the speakers list for the government, which is extended, and when you think about the fact that this bill was before the House in 2001 and has already been fully debated but could not be put through. It is also an interesting bill when you think about the history of similar bills that have been before the House and the Senate, and about the 1980s discussion of this and the recommendation from Senator Harradine's committee about what the appropriate mechanisms were to deal with this problem. It is a terrific bill to bring out the essential ideological nature of the approach of the government and government members. It is one where they are red in tooth and claw, because they have before them the body of trade unionism. It is the one great enemy that they can concentrate on, and they want to turn it into a carcass and then rip it into pieces.

speech.para: The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, who is driving this, like the minister previously, has a series of misnamed bills, full of misnomers, before this parliament. He brought in an unfair dismissals bill that he turned into the `fair dismissals bill'. This is doublespeak and newspeakâa Nineteen Eighty-Four-ism from this minister. We have the same thing here. The title of the bill is `Workplace Relations Amendment'âthat is fair enough, because it is to amend the Workplace Relations Actâ(Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2002', when actually it is about prohibiting a bargaining services fee, not prohibiting compulsory union fees. This is an ideological, propagandistic tag to place upon this bill that entirely misrepresents what it is about. When you go to the explanatory memorandum, you find that item 3 would define the term `bargaining services'. Excuse me, but where is the compulsory union fees part of this in the explanatory memorandum? The bill itself says `bargaining services fee'. It states:

quote.para: Bargaining services means services provided by (or on behalf of) an industrial associationâ

speech.para: that is, an employer or employee associationâ

quote.para: in relation to ... the negotiation, making, certification, operation, extension, variation or termination of the agreement)â

speech.para: that is, under part VIB of the Workplace Relations Act. So in the very definition in the bill this is about bargaining services. It is not about compulsory union fees. That is a propagandistic tag, a sales tag that this government is putting onto this bill.

The United States, given its history of being run most of the time by republican governments, is really not a place that you would think would be union friendly. It is not a place where you would think they would accept anything like compulsory union fees or bargaining services fees. The reality is that for decades in the United States they have legislated to allow for bargaining services fees to be brought into place. They have allowed the unions to seek redress for the money that they have spent bargaining on behalf of their members. When nonmembers of unions get the benefits the unions have bargained for, United States legislation says that the unions should be compensated for that by being able to charge a bargaining services fee. In this country, where there have been attempts to put a bargaining services fee into place, a number of unions have made the key mistake of placing the amount of the bargaining services fee above that of a union fee. That is a key mistake. If you have $750 versus $400 or $500 in union fees it is open to be argued and it is open to be attackedâas the government is trying to do here, saying that this is really trying to force people into the unions.

The core recommendation of the Harradine committee in the 1980s was that a bargaining services fee should be allowed but that that bargaining services fee should be the cost of joining the union, less the industrial aspects. The award mechanisms, which they primarily were in the 1980s, are still operativeâand you can widen this out to workplace agreements and the fact that we have had collective bargaining through the 1980s and 1990s. The Harradine committee effectively said that it is right and proper, given that the unions, and the people who pay their money into the unions, argue for better awards or a better certified agreement under this Workplace Relations Act. I would addâand it is not in the Harradine committee reportâthat you have a simple situation where the minister effectively demands of a union that they represent not only their own members but members who will get a benefit from their bargaining but who are not paying in for it.

It is a pretty simple situation. The Harradine committee said that they thought it was fair that you take a union fee and you extract from that union fee the propagandising that the union would do, their industrial activity, the push and the argument to try and say to people, `You should join our union,' and any affiliation fees that are paid to a political party or paid to other entities. Take all of that out, and the discounted fee relates directly to bargaining services undertaken by the union on behalf of its membersâand on behalf of nonmembers, because they actually get the result. That is an utterly fair approach to take. That is where those unions which have argued for a higher bargaining services fee than the Harradine committee would recommend are out of kilter. They need to rethink their situation and they need to adjust to those circumstancesâwhich have not changed much but they have taken a different tack on it. I will come back to the Harradine committee; I think it is the foundation of a sensible approach.

There are a number of jurisdictions apart from the United StatesâSwitzerland, Sweden, I think, and Israelâwhere bargaining services fees are not only allowed but countenanced by legislation. This is not something that has come from Mars or Jupiter. It is not something that is so outrageous that conservative governments have not allowed for it. When you look at the effect of that, we are still in a situation, as we were in 2001 when this bill was last debated, where these matters are before the Federal Court and the High Court.

If you take a very narrow definition of what is proper in a relationship between an employee and an employer, you can argue that bargaining service fees are not properly part of that, because the key underlying part is whether or not an employer can be forced, through a certified agreement, to deduct from an employee's wages moneys that would go into a union account. We have a bit of experience of that in Parliament House. I am a member of the Community and Public Sector Union. Before 1996, I had a facility within Parliament House where my union fees could be deducted and paid into that union directly from my pay. When this government came in, they made sure that that was not going to happen. They completely prohibited that. So we made a set of other arrangements: I paid those union fees directly out of my own bank account. But it is an ideological approach to say that you should not be able to have a payment on a regular basis if you choose to do it, if you freely decide to do it. If you have the choiceâwhich should be important to people on the other side of the House; they say it is, but it is notâyou should be freely able to say, `I want that taken directly out of my wages before I get them. I do not want to have to muck around to set up another set of arrangements.' That is an indicator, right at the start, of where this mob are going.

They want that spread across the entire work force, but they have directly tied that deduction questionâwhich has been held up in the Federal Court and the High Courtâto the question of the bargaining services fee. I am in the simple situation that there is no bargaining services fee that I would be up for in relation to the Community and Public Sector Union, because their position now is that they cannot directly represent me. They cannot do anything in relation to my position in terms of remuneration and so on, but our party rules say that you have to be a member of a union. In my contribution to that, that cannot be part of it. For me, what was important was a question of being able to deduct from payroll. At source, that is where the government has attempted to attack this, and this is where it is a question of whether it is part of the employer-employee relationship that you can then actually do that.

If we look at the broad range of countriesâgenerally conservative in nature through most of their electionsâthat allow this bargaining service fee, if we think of all of the arguments that have been put forward on the other side of the House about how horrendous a thing it is that someone could actually charge for this, I think you have to start to think of it in a different way. In previous debates, when Arch Bevis, the member for Brisbane, was the shadow minister, he outlined the vast, long list of lawyers on the other side of the Houseâmost of whom are still presentâwho, of course, if they wish to practise as a solicitor or a barrister, have to sign up and pay a fee to their association. As it is for lawyers, so it is for people in the medical profession. The trade union ticket for lawyers and doctors in this country is a university degree in law or medicine. That is their right to work. That is their trade union ticket. Married to that is a simple stipulation that, if you do not sign up to the AMA or if you do not sign up to the other doctors' organisations, if you do not sign up to the College of Surgeons and pay the entry feeâ the bargaining services fee, the compulsory fee, to the College of Surgeonsâif you are not part of the association and you are not paying in, you cannot practise. They are not going to allow you to do it. We all know that, with orthopaedic surgeons, the history of that group is that the entry fee is not only a degree in medicine, the entry fee is access to the college of orthopaedic surgeons. We know too that they have deliberately kept the number of people down. It is a closed shop. There is not open access for everyone in the field of medicine to become an orthopaedic surgeon. They have kept a very tight, very closed shop and there is higher remuneration for orthopaedic surgeons as a result. But you have to pay the association fees. They are the effective equivalent of bargaining services fees.

If we go more broadlyâand the minister's argument here is about freedom of associationâin my case, as someone who wanted payroll deductions made to the Community and Public Sector Union, I did not have a freedom of decision making. I did not have a freedom of choice in regard to that. That is a key element when you are dealing with these issues. I would use another analogy. A lot of people these days live in either blocks of units or in other arrangements where there is a strata title to their property. If you go into one of those places and sign up, you do not have a Torrens title to the land. The strata title means that you join a body corporate. In that body corporate, you have rights but you also have duties and responsibilities. Amongst the duties and responsibilities you have are that you have to pay certain levies. There are two key levies: one is a levy to go into an administrative fund and the other is a levy to go into a sinking fund. The people who are in the body corporate gain protection in terms of the value of their property by putting money into a sinking fund. Over time, as those sinking funds build up, they are there to pay for future maintenance to the property or to fix up future problems that occur with that maintenance. The administrative fee, however, is for the day-to-day workings of that corporate bodyâwhat they do from year to year, the things they have to pay out in preparing tax returns or dealing with electricity, lights, stationery and so on, or pay out to an agent who will do the business for them. I would simply argue that the bargaining services fee is the equivalent of the administrative levy in a corporate bodyâ as you could say it is an equivalent to the entry fee that lawyers, doctors and surgeons have to pay into their entities. It is the equivalent of this. It is for an ongoing maintenance.

Prior to entering parliament and prior to working in the office of former Treasurer and Prime Minister Keating, I was a teacher for just on 10 years. As a member of the Independent Teachers Association teaching in the Catholic school system, I taught with people who paid the money and were in a union and I taught next to people who did not pay any money at all. They had their free choice not to be a member of a unionâfine. We were under an award system. I was a unionist who paid, out of the money that I paid to the union, for my union to bargain with the employer to get a better deal for me as a teacher. For everyone else who was a union member, there was a bargaining services fee that came out of our freely chosen union membership in order to get a better deal from the employer in wages and conditions. It cost a lot to do it. It cost the union a lot and that means it cost the union members, because they are the ones who provide the funds for the union. The people teaching beside me who got the increases in wages and the better conditions did not put a brass razoo into that process. They did not pay a thing: no union feesâ they did not want to be in itâand no bargaining services fee. For nothing, they got all of the benefits.

There is a prohibition on doing it the other way. If you are part of an award or a certified agreement and if you are a union member then the benefit should only go to union members because they are the ones who put the money up in order to get that award or certified agreement made. The people who were not part of that should be excludedâ they should be left to bargain for themselves. So there should be no bargaining services fee in that regard if they had to bargain for themselves. But the laws in this country prohibit that. That is one genuine solution.

Given that we do not have thatâgiven that the benefits flow on to people who do not put any money into the processâit is right and proper to argue that it is reasonable to have a base bargaining services fee. That is the core of what this situation is about. If you are willing by free choice not to join a union, you actually should cop by free choice the fact that you should have to go out and bargain totally to get your increases in wages and conditions. The minister demands through legislation that, under either an award or a certified agreement, people who are not in unions have to get the results. So in that case it is reasonable to say that there are costs associated with this and that therefore it is right and proper that a sensible bargaining services fee be imposed on those people and that it be able to be taken out by automatic payroll deduction.

It is not blindingly difficult to do that. This was clear in the 1980s when the Senate had a major review of this area in the award system and said that it was possible. It said that it was not only possible but in fact right and proper to do it because it was fair to those people who had put their money on the line to try and get an improvement in wages and conditions. For this government, for its members, for those who want to turn the union movement in Australia into a carcass that they can then claw at, the approach we have seen here with this bill and with every other bill that has dealt with unionism demonstrates that this is a mob red in tooth and claw. This is one where it goes to their head; this is one where they can savage the body of trade unionism. Trade unionism is a collection of people in a workplace or across an entity where people have got together to try and do better for themselves. They are ordinary Australian workers trying to protect their families and trying to do the right thing by themselves. This bill is part of the class warfare of this government. It is composed differently from what it was in the past but, as the member for Corio said, it is a Tory bill. This is a conservative thing that should be knocked right out. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is once again my pleasure to be in this House speaking in favour of an important piece of industrial relations legislation, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2002. As the member for Blaxland demonstrated in his speech, industrial relations will continue to be a policy area that will distinguish the two sides of this chamber more and more throughout this term. I think the Australian public will be very grateful that there is a voice in this nation opposing the very stance that the member for Blaxland is purporting to hoodwink the Australian public with. It is an area we have clearly marked out as one which will create significant advantages to the Australian public. We have already seen such advantages in the workplace and on the waterfront with the recent figures that have come out and with the record low industrial disputes that have taken place around Australia.

speech.para: So I am very pleased that the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations continues to introduce bills into this House that will be debated and brought into law to give greater power to employees in the workplace to determine their own fate. In his second reading speech the minister stated:

quote.para: Freedom of association is the cornerstone of the government's vision for a more productive and more prosperous workplace.

speech.para: Indeed, it is. A fundamental freedom in any democratic nation must be the freedom of movement and the freedom to belong or not to belong to organised groups, be they religious, political or industrial in their objectives.

Recently, I had the good fortuneâI cannot say the fun but certainly the good fortuneâof spending nine days walking the Kokoda Trail in Papua New Guinea. We take a lot of our freedoms for granted. Sixty years after the battles in our northern waters to save Australia, we must ask: are we, the members of this parliament, the protectors of such freedoms, freedoms that were hard won by the heroes of Kokoda and those other battles in Milne Bay and the Coral Sea, just to mention a few? The answer to that question must be yes. Those on the other side of the chamber, who cannot distinguish between their service to the nation and their obligations to their union masters, will continue to oppose bills such as these as they are introduced into the chamber.

In May 2001 we saw the introduction of a similar bill to address compulsory union fees for non-union workers. That bill was before the Senate when parliament was prorogued for the federal election. However, in the coalition's 2001 workplace relations policy, the government again reiterated its commitment in this area. This bill confirms the government's resolve on that commitment. While the Workplace Relations Act already protects certain freedom of association and freedom from discrimination rights, this bill extends that protection to the imposition of compulsory bargaining service fees. This government supports the right of workers to decide whether or not they want to join a union and rejects any notion of compulsory union membership. The opposition, on the other hand, conveniently has an industrial relations policy that fails to deal with this issue. In his address, the member for Blaxland gave the impression that bargaining service fees do not equate to compulsory union fees, that the two are separate items. That is a great con. On the surface it may appear to be the case that a bargaining service fee is not a compulsory union fee, but the effect is that Australian workers who are not members of unions are conned by that statement; they will be hoodwinked.

In recent years, we have seen a dramatic increase in provisions under certified agreements requiring the payment of bargaining service fees by non-union members. Quite often these fees, which are purported to be charged for services rendered over the bargaining period, are actually higher than union membership fees. So one must then ask: is there a legitimate reason for pursuing such a practice? Surely any reasonable person could see through such an obvious facade. In fact, unions are merely using this type of provision to coerce non-union workers into joining the union movement. Why would I pay $750 for a bargaining service fee when it would cost me perhaps $400, $450 or $500 to be a member of the union? It is a con. It is coercion in order to get people to join the union movement.

The Victorian Police Association, as was mentioned by the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business in their submission in 2001 to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee, is a prime example. The Victorian Police Association proposal to charge a $750 bargaining service fee to non-union members while the union membership fee was only $420 is a perfect example of the kind of coercive intent I am referring to. The member for Blaxland is just one of the voices on the other side attempting to mask the real intent of this practice and to say that it does not equate to compulsory union fees.

Unions often attempt to hide behind the principle of user pays; in fact, they have distorted the truth by claiming that principle applies. User pays involves an exchange, I would have thought, between two willing and informed parties. Trade practices legislation exists that prevents regular businesses from providing unsolicited services and then demanding payment. Why, then, should it not be so for trade associations as well? In a competitive market, businesses must rely on the reputation and the quality of their service or product in order to attract customers. Unions should be encouraged to adopt the same approach to attracting new members. Instead, for obvious reasons, unions prefer to rely on bargaining service fees as a means of keeping their numbers up and, hence, their coffers full. If they are struggling with membership, they should go out and demonstrate the added value rather than coercing people to join through the back door by having a bargaining service fee.

The usual rhetoric behind bargaining service feesâand often we find that these are in the $500 rangeâis that they are to cover bargaining negotiation costs required to achieve benefits to which non-union members also have access. Clearly, when you look at examples like the one mentioned earlier about the Victorian Police Association this seems a little far-fetched, to say the least. Perhaps a more realistic view of the situation is that these fees are, in fact, just a de facto way of compelling workers to join the union movement. The unions reap the benefits of a larger membership base and, of course, the effect is that there is a dramatic increase in the size of their respective coffers. If they could con the other 5.6 million non-union fee paying workers into paying, they would end up better off to the tune of $2.8 billion. So there are big stakes involved for the union movement. It is no wonder that members on the other side of the House find it very difficult to support the government on this bill, because they know that their masters in the union movement need that money. Of course, we know where that money in turn flows to, and I will say a bit more about that in a moment.

Unions have been encouraged to pursue this type of arrangement by the ACTU, which in June 2000 passed a motion calling on the federal government to legislate to allow all unions to charge such fees. This call was reflected in the heading `ACTU seeks new fee' in the Canberra Times on 30 June. Let us have a look at why they were moved to pass such a motion in June 2000. Let us look at some of the figures that we have on union membership that have come out in recent times. If we go back 20 years to around May 1982, we will find that 49.5 per cent of all employees were members of the union movement; that is, 2.5 million workers in Australia were members of the union movement. In 20 yearsâand a good 13 years of those were under the helm of an ALP federal governmentâwe have seen trade union membership drop from 2.5 million to 1.9 million. It now stands at only 24 per cent of all employees. A good percentage of that, of course, will be in the Australian Public Service and various state public services around this country. So there are big stakes involved and, based on the rewards they could reap from having such a bargaining service fee, I dare say they will be opposing this bill tooth and nail all the way.

There seems to be confusion, even among members of the Labor Party, about the worth of this strategy. The member for Barton expressed his reservation in relation to bargaining fees in the Australian on 26 November 2001:

quote.para: Before I felt comfortable with that concept, I'd want to know why unions are unable to recruit members in a particular areaâ

speech.para: and again when he says that unionsâ

quote.para: ... can't expect to control the whole workplace agenda, given they have coverage of such a small percentage.

speech.para: And so it is. If they were representing an increased percentage of workers, imagine the kind of power that they could wreak around the countryside and exert on their parliamentary representatives. So even among the Labor Party ranks there is scepticism. What is Labor's position? Item 45 of the most recent ALP policyâALP industrial relations policy 2000âallows union service fees by couching them in terms of allowing trade unions:

quote.para: ... to take action on behalf of their members and on behalf of workers generally.

speech.para: Where does the opposition leader stand? Is a $500 Crean tax on 5.6 million workers to be tolerated? Of course not. It is plain wrong and yet another example of the bad policy being put forward by the Labor Party.

The CEPU has been pursuing this strategy. In 1998-99, the CEPU gave $463,121.73 to the ALP; in 1999-2000, that figure rose to $583,274. That is a substantial contribution to the ALP by one union, a union that is very much at the front line in introducing a bargaining services fee. With the new Crean tax, I shudder to imagine how much policy they will be able to buy from the Labor Party should things continue. I also shudder to think how much of that money is going to their marginal seats in order to unseat this government, because we know that money flows all the way through.

I go out there when I run my campaign at each election and I have to convince people that I am worth supporting, in terms of votes and financial contributions to help me with some of the costs; the ALP just walk up to an election with their chequebook already filled by the union movement. I was at a railway station during an election and a guy next to me said, `Which electorate am I in?' He had no idea which electorate he was in, because he had come from the other side of townâ someone had paid him to stand at the railway station, handing out brochures. Of course, people like this had no idea who they were supporting; all they knew was: `The union movement told me to be here. I am here. By the way, here's my money as well.' It is a sham; it is laziness on the part of the union movement and on the part of the ALP that they want the Australian public to be roped into some sort of compulsory system of providing money in the first instance to the union movement and in the second instance to their mouthpieces in the federal parliament.

The recent decision by the Federal Court in the Electrolux case reveals that the bargaining services fee would not be enforceable under the Workplace Relations Act. This is due to the fact that the court determined that the bargaining services fees clause could not be validly included in certified agreements. Bargaining services fees, it was decided, did not satisfy the requisite employer-employee relationship as required by section 170LI of the Workplace Relations Act. The judgment focused on several claims by the unions, but of most interest is how the Federal Court characterised the union claim for a compulsory bargaining fee. The major features of this claim are that it required, firstly, for Electrolux to inform employees who are non-union members that they are required to pay the unions a bargaining fee of $500 per year; and, secondly, for Electrolux to provide a direct debit system to pay the bargaining agents fee to the unions. What gall! The court notes that, in essence, what is then being created is an agency relationship. This occurs since the employer collects the fee and then passes it on to the unions. The agency, it would seem, is created for the benefit of the union rather than the employees, who would also face an involuntarily imposed fee.

Justice Merkel in this case also speculated that it was unlikely that the involuntary bargaining fee would be allowed under the freedom of association provisions in part XA of the act. He even goes so far as to say:

quote.para: ... I doubt that those difficulties can be overcome by altering the form of the claim, or by phrasing it so as to appear non-discriminatory, when it is plain that, if acceded to, the claim is intended to operate in a discriminatory manner against non-union employees.

speech.para: Despite the ruling in the Electrolux case in favour of the government's stance on the issue, the government still believes it is necessary to once and for all exhibit clear legislative purpose on the issue. Furthermore, if such bargaining service fee clauses are invalidly included in many agreements, they should be removed so as not to give them a false sense of legitimacy. The bill will streamline the approach to future certified agreements by eliminating the possible inclusion of such clauses.

It should also be noted that the proposed agreement put forward by the unions in the Electrolux case, if approved, would have lasted until 31 March 2003. This would have meant that any new employees entering the work force during that time would have been subject to the compulsory fees for services previously rendered by the unions. How could it be justified that they rendered any service if the employee had not even worked there during that time? It is ludicrous for the Labor Party to refuse to admit the need for reform in this area. They need to come out and admit that their support for bargaining service fees merely constitutes a cheap con designed to compel worker involvement in unions to arrest a downward spiral in member numbers.

This bill will ensure that the freedom of association provisions in the Workplace Relations Act can be realised by all workers. It also protects workers' rights by prohibiting retaliatory measures from unions, employers and others merely because a worker has elected to exercise the right to freedom of association. Misrepresentation as to the liability to pay such a fee is also addressed and prohibited through the bill. Through slight adjustments to the IRC powers to approve agreements, the system will be streamlined to allow only agreement not containing such provisions to be certified.

As all in the House will be aware, this government is committed to upholding freedom in all its forms. These freedoms were hard won. As we celebrate and commemorate what took place 60 years ago in the battles to save Australia, as we commemorate the deeds of all those who sacrificed their lives for these hard-won freedoms, let us make sure that, as members of this chamber, we continue to uphold the freedom of association to which ordinary Australian workers are entitled. As was revealed in the budget, Australia has again shown its commitment to defending freedom abroad. Let us show our commitment to demonstrate the freedom of those right here in Australia by supporting this bill.

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Deakin, who so eloquently laid out the case why the Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2002 should not even be necessary in the parliament of Australia. However, the fact that it is necessary at all is a sad reflection on the union movement and on many of those opposite. The fact that it is necessary is yet another stark example of how those opposite will always choose the interests of union leaders and their own party finances over the rights, choices and freedoms of individual Australian workers. The fact that it is necessary also dissolves some of the myth-making we have seen since the last election about how those opposite are seeking to modernise themselves and change their relationship with the union movement.

speech.para: This prohibition of compulsory union fees bill is necessary because the union movement is trying to force workers it cannot force to join their union to pay a fee in any event. If they cannot enforce compulsory membership, they will enforce compulsory payment. To simply get a job, the Labor Party and the union movement insist that Australians be compelled to belong to a union. That is their policy. If they ever have a chance to implement it again, they will, but in the meantime they will settle for just forcing you to pay anyway.

That is what the bill is about. It is about forcing workers who do not wish to join a union to pay a fee to a union anyway. The farce of this situation has been well exposed by many members in this debate and by many spokesmen for various organisations outside the House. Mr Andrew Craig, the Executive Director of Queensland Commerce, said:

quote.para: Bargaining fees are simply a poorly disguised attempt to introduce compulsory unionism.

speech.para: Similarly, HIA spokesman Glenn Simpson put it quite eloquently:

quote.para: It's taxation without representation. How would you feel being forced to pay for a service you didn't ask for, didn't want and may have even strongly opposed. It's just a way of using the industrial relations system to extract money from people who don't want to be union members.

speech.para: I could not have put it better myself. That last statement says so much about the union movement and where it finds itself today in that more and more Australian workers find the union movement irrelevant to their day-to-day concerns and, as the member for Deakin said, of little value or benefit to them. That is why we find ourselves debating this bill here today. Even if unions cannot extract a membership from a worker, they will settle to try to extract the fee. You need only look at union membership figures to see the story of decline and shrinkage.

The member for Deakin went through some of the key statistics, but it is worth tracking them with some of those opposite who had responsibility for running the union movement. When the current Leader of the Opposition was President of the ACTU in the mid- to late-1980s, union membership stood at about 45 per cent. By the time he left to hand the baton over to the present member for Batman, who took over in 1990, it had declined to 40 per cent. When the current member for Batman left to hand the presidency of the ACTU to the current member for Throsby, it had declined to 31 per cent. When she just dropped the baton to run for preselection and entered this House, it had fallen to 25 per cent. Over three ACTU presidents, who are now members of the parliamentary Labor Party, union membership fell from 45 per cent to 25 per cent and it hovers a little below that today.

As the member for Deakin pointed out, if everything the union movement and the Labor Party said was true, if everything those opposite said in the debate was true, if the services that the union movement provided were so valuable, if the representation they provided was so vital, you would not have seen a fall in union membership. In fact, you would have seen an increase or at least a constancy about it. However, the fact that we have not seen an increase and that we have seen a massive decrease speaks volumes for what Australian workers really think about the union movement and its relevance to their day-to-day lives.

The Labor Party know this is the case and they know that it is their big problem. Their union base is shrinking and a number of members on the other side have, in recent months, written, spoken, pontificated and engaged in newspaper article wars about the need for the ALP to modernise its structures. The member for Hunter is just one of those who have been engaged in that debate. In the Newcastle Herald in December last year, the member for Hunter spoke about a number of failings of the modern Labor Party, including the 60-40 rule and how that needed to be changed. He also spoke about his wife, who runs a small business. He said:

quote.para: My wife is a self-employed beauty therapist and runs her own salon. The thought of forking out hundreds of dollars each year to join a union which can be of no assistance to her whatsoever is an anathema to her.

speech.para: Of course he is right, but the tragedy for those opposite is that even though he knows it is right and he knows the situation is an anathema, he will still come in here and vote against this legislation when it is put to the Houseâalong with every other member opposite. In doing so, they will be voting for compulsion and for unrepresentative union leaders who cannot recruit members through the virtue of their organisation but only through compulsion of membershipâor if this bill is not passed, through the straight confiscation of fees.

As I said a little earlier, in the months since the last election we have seen and heard a great deal by Labor Party figures about their need to modernise. That debate has centred on something which is really quite small: whether the Labor Party should reduce its representation of unions in party bodies from 60 per cent to 50 per cent. We saw on the weekend the Leader of the Opposition fly here to Canberra to address a party conference and walk away empty handed yet again. It is worth going back, because on attaining the leadership of the Labor Party six months agoâalmost to the dayâthe opposition leader set himself the goal of reducing union representation. Six months later he is no closer. But the important point in all this, in my view, is that the Leader of the Opposition is not genuinely trying to modernise Labor. The unions should not have any fear. What he is desperately trying to do is dress up a very minor changeâ60 per cent down to 50 per cent of union representation in party bodiesâto pretend to the electorate that Labor has changed. When he conjured up this PR exercise, it was all meant to be simple, but it speaks volumes that the union movement will not even allow him a simple change. So in trying to get a small change, he has been slapped down by those in the Labor Party and the union leadership.

The real point is this: if the Leader of the Opposition and those opposite were really concerned about modernising their party structures, they would not start with the 60-40 rule, the 50-50 rule or whatever it is that they are trying to change. They would start right here on this bill, because it goes right to the heart of the fundamental freedoms that the member for Deakin spoke of. They would come in here and they would say, `This is a matter of important principle. It is the simplest principle. We admit failure. We acknowledge the farce.' They would say to the union movement that the days of forcing people to join or pay a feeâas this bill seeks to preventâare over and that we live in a modern world where, if you want members, like any other organisation, you have got to go out and get them and convince them of the relevance of the union movement, rather than just arrogantly assume that role and conscript everyone to the cause. But they will not, and the reason they will not is not necessarily that they disagree with what I said; it is that they are just as hostage to the union movement as the union leaders are. That is because the system they are engaged in is one they cannot walk away fromâit is a life support system for the Labor Party.

It works like this: unions extract compulsory fees which are donated to the ALP and which fund the campaigns of those opposite. That is the point every worker needs to understand. You pretty much cannot join a union in Australia without donating money to the ALP and contributing to their election campaigns. The worker has part of his or her wages taken. The money sits in the union, and then at election time a portion of it goes to the Labor Party election campaign fund. No matter your view, your stance or how you wish to vote, when you are making up your mind on how to vote, if you have been forced to be a member of a union or you have had a fee extracted, you know that that money is going to the Labor Partyâevery election, every year.

Since 1996 more than $27 million has been donated to the ALP by trade unions. If I ran through the list, it would take until question time. Here are just some: $200,000 from the New South Wales CFMEU energy division; $53,000 from the South Australian shoppies union; $8,500 from the WA branch of the Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union; $7,000 from the Queensland CFMEU construction division. The list goes on and on for pages. So if you work in industriesâand some of those people are some of the lowest paid workers in our countryâ and you are paying your union fees and you are wondering where they are going, at election time, when you see television and newspaper advertisements, realise that you have made a contribution to that campaign, whether you like it or not. For the same reason that happens, the Labor Party, with the same arrogant view as that of the union movement, would probably justify it by saying that they are representing you, whether you like it or not.

As I said at the outset, this bill should not even have come before this House. It is here because the union movement is trying to subvert and bypass the voluntary membership provisions of the Workplace Relations Act. It is before us because those opposite rely on forcing Australian workers to finance the union movement who, in turn, finance them. When they vote against it, every Australian worker should know that those opposite are voting to force them to pay part of their salary to a union so that unions can give them a political donation. This bill deserves to be passed. It should be passed without dissent, and if those opposite were not captured and owned by the union movement, it would be.

talk.start.para: âI compliment the member for Deakin, the member for Casey and, yesterday, my colleague the member for Dawson on their fine words in relation to this very important bill. This bill focuses on a matter of principle: what is fair and reasonable, what is decent and what is just. The subject of this bill is of concern to every Australian who believes in a fair goâthat is, compulsory union fees or, if you like, bargaining service fees. I believe that in a democracy there is no place for the dead hand of compulsory union fees. Compulsory union fees are the domain of trade unions which are irrelevant to their members and irrelevant to the communities in which they operate. A union which represents its members well does not need compulsory union feesâbargaining service fees. A union which represents its members well should attract a strong following by virtue of the services it provides its members. It should not require or force families to pay up to $500 for bargaining service fees. A union which represents its members well should survive in the labour market on its own merit. It may be that, in the past, many unions which have been controlled by members opposite would not have survived except for compulsory union fees. It is an interesting thought. I say to those members opposite: tell your union mates to take the challenge of the brave new world where unions will need to survive on merit and not by virtue of compulsory fees.

speech.para: This bill is a little gem, as it serves to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to prevent the Industrial Relations Commission from certifying or varying any agreement that contains a provision requiring the payment of a bargaining service fee. This bill serves to amend clause 298Y of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to make it clear that a certified agreement is void to the extent that it requires payment of a bargaining service fee. This bill is indeed a fair bill. Not only does it outlaw the disgraceful practice of compulsory union fees but it is balanced because it prohibits employers from discriminating against those who refuse to pay union feesâor should I say the bargaining service fee. So you can see there is equity. There are obligations on the employer as well as obligations on the union, and rightly so.

The bill is a fair bill because it prohibits unions from encouraging or inciting others to take discriminatory action against those who are merely exercising their democratic rights: their democratic right not to pay trade union fees, their democratic right not to pay money to an organisation that does not represent their interest, and their democratic right not to pay money to an organisation with a political agenda different from their own. This bill will prevent a trade union or industrial organisation from demanding a bargaining service fee from another person. Dear oh dear, it could be a very lonely time down at Trades Hall when this bill is passed! This bill will prevent a person from making a false or misleading representation about another person's liability to pay a bargaining service fee. This bill is a balanced bill. It applies equally to employer associations and trade unions alike. No trade union or employer group which is truly representative of its members should fear this bill. On the contrary, it should welcome it.

We are yet to see if members opposite support this bill. We are yet to see if members opposite believe that the trade union movement is sufficiently relevant to its members to survive without those despicable compulsory trade union fees. I suspect that the union movement does not feel it is up to the challenge of surviving in the brave new world. I suspect it is still going to attempt to lean on that dreaded method of obtaining members: compulsory union fees. Members opposite will probably dance to the tune of the ACTU, as is their habit, and will ignore the democratic rights of ordinary Australiansâthe democratic rights of fair and reasonable people who would seek to choose not to have to pay compulsory union fees.

This government has been focused on looking to the future. The budget which the Treasurer brought down gets the settings right for our economic prosperity. The Intergenerational Report looks forward to 2042. But with members opposite it is a case of back to the future; back to the good old Labor dogma; back to the old waysâthey cannot help themselvesâand backing trade unions which are irrelevant in the labour market and which must conscript their members, not obtain members by virtue of the services they provide. For instance, I think you would agree with me that if the member for Lilley was walking down the street and a shopkeeper came out and forced him to buy a bag of bananasâI must say that my electorate of Cowper produces some very fine bananas indeed around the areas of Coffs Harbour and Woolgoolgaâthat he did not want, he would be a bit upset, and rightly so. In the same way as ordinary Australians have the right to choose not to buy a bag of bananas, they should have the right to choose not to pay compulsory union fees. Why do members opposite continue to support those dinosaurs of the labour market in this matter? I call on members opposite to support the rights of workers and ordinary Australians to exercise their democratic right as to whether they pay money to a union or whether they do not pay money to a union.

This bill is indeed a good bill. It is a bill which guarantees the rights of the individual to choose, and that is what we are about here. We are about choice; we are about the ability of a person to choose between not being represented in the labour market by a union or being so represented and paying for that opportunity. Choosing to pay union fees should be an act of will and not occur by compulsion. We would not countenance any form of extortion in any other area of our activities or in any other area of our community, so we should give the power to this bill to give workers their freedom to choose. I do not agree much with what Bob Carr says, but recently he said:

quote.para: You can't put a tax on other members of the workforce and a state can't require the collection of union fees from non-unionists.

speech.para: I would have to agree with him on that. Also, the Western Australian workplace relations minister, John Kobelke said:

quote.para: We think unions need to get out and provide services to their members and attract members on the basis of what they can offer.

speech.para: I think that is totally appropriate. The member for Casey chronicled the rather dramatic decline in trade union membership under the stewardship of a number of former leaders of the union movement who now sit opposite. Those membership levels would not be decliningâthey would be increasingâif the union movement were truly relevant to the people whom they masquerade to represent. If it were truly relevant, we would see the number of trade unionists swelling. But in fact that is not happening; it is going the other way. Membership is declining, and that shows that unions are not relevant to their members. They are not representing their interests in the way that members would wish to happen.

I maintain that compulsory union fees have no place in this country, and this bill gives effect to that. It outlaws those dreaded compulsory union fees. If the Leader of the Opposition were in touch with ordinary, everyday Australiansâif he were in touch with the people out thereâhe would be supporting this bill. It is a good bill. It preserves the right of choice. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: â The coalition's 2001 workplace relations election policy was about choice and reward. They are two words that I believe are the key to progress right around the country. That is why I speak in support of the Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill 2002. It is about choice. What the National Party and this government are about is the ability of people to choose where they work and to choose to come to an agreement with their employer. It is about choice. It is about choice right around Australia, whether you choose to work for yourself or whether you choose to work for somebody else. The minute you interfere with that choice you put in jeopardy the reasons we are in this chamber and the reasons we are all proud to be in this country and a part of it.

speech.para: The bill seeks to address the union movement's attempts to circumnavigate the prohibition of compulsory union fees by imposing service fees. While unions probably find it hard to make the fees compulsory, they are certainly coercing workers to join. This is undemocratic and, without doubt, harks back to the old days of standover intimidation. I came to this place, like all of us here, to try to make this country even better than it is today.

Members this morning have spoken about the reasons for the union movement's shrinking. The plain fact is that, if an organisation represents people well enough, they will be very pleased to join it. Prior to coming to this House, I was President of the New South Wales Farmers Association, which represented about 50 per cent of the serious farmers in the state. Those farmers joined the association of their own free will. The association never attempted to coerce a memberâin fact, I would not have been a part of it if it had. We dealt with issues that revolved around a free world market and not, as unions do, in a regulated domestic labour market. It was a much harder job, with a much higher membership. That says quite a lot of things. People are not joining the union movement, because they are very unhappy with it. They do not like being stood over, they do not like being tricked and they do not like having to pay a service fee or a union fee unless they voluntarily choose to do so.

A similar organisation is the Country Women's Association. Obviously I am not a member, but many country women are. It operates in a very similar vein to the New South Wales Farmers Association and probably has as large a membership. These organisations do not coerce anyone. Both charge far less than the union movements do for the average person to be a member, and they have far greater success in attracting that membership. If you represent your people and do a good job, you will without doubt reap the rewards of increased membership. Can you imagine the outrage if the government tried to legislate that everybody in their electorates had to be members of their party? It is not much different.

It has become standard practice for the trade unions to demand a service fee without consent when they collectively bargain and, as I understand it, do not seek the views of the workers involved. This fee is quite often set above the union fee; in other words, the unions are saying, `It is actually cheaper for you to join the movement than to pay the service fee.' That is the act of an organisation that knows it cannot attract members. Membership is about choice. What possible reasons could there be for either chamber to vote against this amendment to the Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill other than for financial greed and because the union movement cannot attract members? Not long after the election, the Labor Party talked about the need to become less union oriented. The best way to do that would be to pass this bill in both chambers.

Surely we have gone beyond the time when everything was done by intimidationâ `If you are not with us you are against us.' The fundamental right of an employee to choose whether or not he wants to be represented by a union is paramount, in the same way that the introduction of compulsory secret ballots amongst employees to get an absolutely true vote as to whether strike action should happen is true democracy. This bill seeks to underline that fact by taking away intimidation and coercion.

The ACTU formally supports unions pursuing compulsory fees in collective agreements, which attempts to give their demands a legal status or a legal aura where obviously they cannot have it. This bill should not be necessary. It is something that the opposition and the unions should be ashamed of. By including such provisions in collective agreements, unions are able to use the cover of a majority employee vote to coerce non-union members who may have voted against the agreement to pay the fee or to join the union, and thereby deny the right to freedom of association.

I think it was mentioned earlier that the Premier of New South Wales is against unions being able to collect this type of fee and is against compulsory unionism. It is wonderful to hear Bob Carr make a statement like that. I wish he would respect farmers' rights in the same way because he is certainly not concerned about what it costs them when dealing with them in what I call his `environmental righteous manner'. We have also heard that the Western Australian Labor government seeks to disassociate itself from this type of action.

This bill has been introduced to address all those certified agreements that contain bargaining fee service clauses. As I said earlier, one of the great problems is that they are setting the bargaining fee higher than union membership fees and therefore making it cheaper for people to join a union than pay the fee. The bill will not prevent contractual arrangements between a union and a nonmember. That is free choice and I support free choice absolutely.

It has been said in debating these sorts of bills that, when we try to provide free choiceâwhen we try to keep Australia open to those people who wish to make an arrangement between themselves and their employer without being coerced into adding other aspects to itâthey have no hope of passing through the Senate because the Labor Party will not support them. If the Labor Party wants to fix up its problems, it will have to look very hard at whether intimidation in the union way is the way for Australia because in recent times Australians have said that they have had enough of it. I commend this bill to the House.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr ABBOTT
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âIt seems that almost no-one has a good word for these compulsory union fees except the ACTU and some members of this House who feel that it is vital to support the ACTU line. Even decent, honest members of the ALP, who are in a position to express themselves without fear of ACTU coercion, believe that there is something wrong with compulsory union fees. As we have just heard from the member for Parkes, the Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr, said:

quote.para: You can't put a tax on other members of the work force and the state can't require the collection of union fees from non-unionists.

speech.para: The Western Australian workplace relations minister, John Kobelke, has said:

quote.para: We think unions need to get out and provide services to their members and attract ... membersâ

speech.para: on the basis ofâ

quote.para: ... what they can offer.

speech.para: Even the federal shadow minister for workplace relations, the member for Barton, said:

quote.para: Before I felt comfortable with that conceptâ

speech.para: that is to say, the concept of compulsory union feesâ

quote.para: I would want to know why unions are unable to recruit members in a particular area.

speech.para: That is what he said late last year. It is not quite what he is saying now because, unfortunately, the member for Barton's decent instincts have been overridden by the instructions of his caucus, in turn operating on the basis of instructions from the ACTU. But nearly everyone, when asked to consider this matter free of that kind of organisational heavying, realised that there is something wrong with the idea of extracting compulsory levies from nonmembers. It is a little bit like coming along and saying, `Political parties provide everyone with a service. If we did not exist, democracy under the Westminster system would not be able to function. We provide the vital quality control in the system that enables citizens to be confident that the vast majority of their members will be reasonable, decent people. We do this service for everyone, therefore you must all pay a levy to one or other of the political parties.' Of course that is a ridiculous position to put forward, yet what we are seeing is the industrial equivalent of compulsory levies to political parties. What we are seeing, in fact, is industrial conscription. That is what members opposite are supporting with their attitude to the Workplace Relations Amendment (Prohibition of Compulsory Union Fees) Bill.

This bill that the government has put before the House today is designed to ensure that freedom of association is a reality in practice, as well as in theory, in Australian workplaces. It is designed to stop the practice which is now becoming widespread in sections of Australian industry of trying to bring about Clayton's compulsory unionismâcompulsory unionism through the backdoorâby imposing on all workers in a workplace, through the vehicle of a certified agreement, a bargaining agents clause, as it is called, but which is, in effect, a compulsory union levy. Hundreds of certified agreements, particularly in the Victorian construction industry, now have these bargaining agents clauses included in them. The bargaining agents clause usually provides that non-union members should pay a levy of up to $500. Invariably the levy is set at a higher rate than union membership fees. My department advises me that there are bargaining agents clauses in more than five per cent of the certified agreements which were sought to be registered in the last 12 months. So this really is a blatant attempt by unions, that cannot persuade people to join, to coerce them to join through the device of these fees.

The Industrial Relations Commission has considered this matter and a single senior member of the commission has, indeed, said that these clauses breach the freedom of association principles. Nevertheless, a single member found technical reasons not to strike these clauses out of certified agreements and that decision was upheld at the level of a full bench.

Subsequently, the Federal Court has found that these clauses are actually unenforceable, but they are still there in hundreds, if not thousands, of certified agreements and they will proliferate if this House, this parliament, does not pass legislation before it. Let no-one be in any doubt: coercion is taking place in the workplaces of Australia to try to ensure that people do sign up to a union and that, if they do not sign up, they pay these fees. After the evidence that has been made available day by day to the Cole royal commission into the construction industry, anyone who does not believe that coercion is taking place in the workplaces of Australia plainly believes in the tooth fairy. Although members opposite, I suppose, think that you can have higher spending, lower taxes and a bigger surplus so maybe they do, after all, believe in the tooth fairy.

I want to address some of the generic points made by members opposite. First of all, members opposite claim that these compulsory union fees are in fact some kind of an industrial version of the fee for service principle. In order for something to be a valid exhibition of the fee for service principle, you have to actually ask for it. Informed consent is an essential part of anything that is reasonably described as fee for service. There is no informed consent in the case of these compulsory union fees. If a business sought to charge someone for a so-called service that was not requested and was not necessarily needed, that would be nothing but a rort. It is in fact illegal to do so under various pieces of corporate legislation. If someone walked past my house and decided that it was in need of a bit of paint, pulled out the paint brush and started painting without asking my permission and, then, when I came home tried to present me with a bill for hundreds of dollars, that would be nothing but a rort, a rip-off and a racket. These compulsory union fees are the industrial equivalent of that.

The point has been made by members opposite that this is some kind of industrial version of the mutual obligation principleâthat if you get the `benefit' of union work you should pay the price of union membership. I have to say that it is a pretty dubious benefit in many instances. I think most of the unions that we are familiar with are not benefiting their members and other people in the industry. In fact, if the AMWU and the CFMEU are any guide, these unions specialise in destroying the jobs of everyone in their industries, let alone the jobs of their members. So it is indeed an extremely dubious benefit. The fact is that, for something to be legitimately described as a kind of mutual obligation arrangement, the benefit in question has to be sought. You have to ask for a benefit before anyone can say that there is some kind of mutual obligation or reciprocal obligation involved.

The third generic point made by members opposite is that the government's legislation in some way infringes ILO conventions. Let me read to the House paragraph 100 of an ILO general survey which says:

quote.para: ... systems which prohibit union security practices in order to guarantee the right not to join an organization, as well as systems which authorize such practices, are compatible with the Convention.

speech.para: The relevant convention is ILO Convention No. 87. So, plainly, this bill does comply with Australia's obligations to the ILO. I want to take up a couple of particular points that were raised by the shadow minister, the member for Barton, and I think he really did struggle to fill his half-hour with relevant objections to the government's bill. He said that, first of all, the bill had the wrong title. That is a very weighty objection! Let me point out to the member for Barton that only unions are seeking to apply these compulsory levies; there is no talk of business organisations seeking to impose compulsory levies on their nonmembers, even though they could probably use the money. The fact is that it is a perfectly adequate title for the bill.

The member for Barton said that there was no proof of coercion offered. I do not think the member for Barton has been reading his press clippings. Every day we hear of rampant coercion and intimidation in the construction industry which, of course, is the very place where most of these compulsory union levy clauses exist. Listening to the member for Barton I could not help thinking that, while he is no doubt genuinely and sincerelyâas are his colleaguesâagainst coercion in general, it seems that they have never found a piece of coercion in particular that they cannot find some kind of justification to support.

The final point that the member for Barton made was that this bill in some way pre-empts a decision of the Federal Court. This House has never regarded itself as excluded from legislation because there has been a decision by the Federal Court. The fact is that the relevant decision by the Federal Court is under appeal anyway and, in any event, even if that particular decision is upheld on appeal, unless the House passes this legislation, these clauses will remain in hundreds, if not thousands, of certified agreements and the union activists, the union heavies, will be fanning out across the workplaces, trying to demand that non-union members pay these fees.

If this practice of compulsory union levies under the guise of bargaining agents fees is not struck down, the reality is that up to six million non-union members in Australia will face, over time, paying $500 a year in a union tax. I do not think this would be good for them, I do not think it would be good for Australia and, ultimately, I do not even think it would be good for the union movement, because it is old-style unionism in all its ugliness and coercion. If the union movement is to have a dynamic future in this country it must move with the times. It must sell itself; it must persuade people to belong rather than expect the state or the party to do that job for it.

Listening to the member for Barton, I felt that his problem was not so much that this particular bill pre-empts a Federal Court decision so much as the fact that it pre-empts the ALP resolving the struggle for its soul. Right now, members opposite are engaged in a bitter internal debate over what their party really stands for. It is a debate which is far from resolved. On the one hand, there are the forces of light, including the member for Kingston; on the other hand, there are the forces of darkness, led for the time being by the member for Rankin. The forces of light believe that the ALP must be a genuinely democratic party rather than a union quasi-dictatorship. The member for Rankin, for reasons best known to himself, seems to have put himself at the head of the old guardâno doubt because big Bill Ludwig has provided the instruction of the day. In all of this, the member for Barton, who is a thoroughly decent human being and a highly intelligent former union lawyer, strikes me as the Tariq Aziz of Australian politicsâthe reasonable face of a union dictatorship. He did his best with this bill, but I am afraid it was a thoroughly unconvincing effort. The bill should be passed by the House, and I commend the bill to the House.
