talk.start.para: âIt is fitting that we should be debating the Space Activities Amendment Bill 2002 on this day because it was on this day that the second Star Wars movie, Attack of the Clones, was released. I have had the opportunity of having a briefing on that. The movie Attack of the Clones, in summary, was about a war that took place involving the clones. It was a war that was referred to by Obi-Wan Kenobi all those years ago in the original Star Wars movieâObi-Wan Kenobi told Luke Skywalker that he fought with Luke's father in the clone wars. We subsequently learn, in that first trilogy, that Luke Skywalker's father was Darth Vader. So it is fitting that we are debating this legislation today for all those fans of space activity.

speech.para: I am also informed that there was no definition of outer space provided in the movie last night, so it is convenient that a definition of outer space be provided in this legislation here today. That definition is `100 kilometres from the earth'. I thought people would be interested that we do know what we are talking about when we are talking about space, whether it be in relation to Attack of the Clones or the Space Activities Amendment Bill 2002.

The major amendments made by the bill include the capping, at $750 million, of the amount of insurance required to be procured by proponents for each launch. It provides for the Commonwealth to accept liability for third-party Australian nationals above the insured amount for up to $3 billion. It is a fact that the Commonwealth is already liable, under the United Nations convention, for damage to foreign third parties, so this relates to Australian nationals. The bill also provides for a tightening of the safety test being applied to commercial applicants for instruments, by making provision for a test of risk that is `as low as reasonably practicable' instead of `sufficiently low' as is the case in the current legislation.

The bill also provides for a less onerous application and assessment process and a lower fee regime for scientific and educational organisations. The argument here is that scientific and educational launches are usually on a one-off basis and do not involve the construction of major infrastructure, and for these reasons such organisations should not be subject to the same licensing requirements as commercial launches. I think that is fair enough. Finally, the bill contains a number of minor administrative and technical amendments, including defining the point at which the act becomes effective, clarifying the fee regime and making provision for an annual review of a space licence.

Labor will not be opposing this bill, but I do intend to move a second reading amendment which goes to the question of the government's priorities in providing insurance cover of more than $3 billion to a commercial operation when around Australia it is well known that there are school fetes and country shows and sporting associations that are struggling under the weight of exorbitant insurance premiums. Those organisations around Australia have been screaming out for some relief but the government has declined to provide it. I think that that reflects an unusual set of priorities, to put it mildly. While we do not oppose this piece of legislation, I think it is important for the government to hear the calls of small organisations, just as it hears the call of large organisationsâin this case, in assisting with space activities.

The second reading amendment also goes to the point that the government has managed to identify and provide $100 million in assistance for this project on Christmas Island. Again, we are not opposing thatâthat money appears to be coming from the strategic investment coordination programâbut it is a sad indictment of the government that, at the same time, it has frozen the R&D Start program. I want to talk about that, because it again reflects an unusual set of priorities. The R&D Start program is an important program for this country's future because it assists small and medium sized enterprises that are engaged in research and development activity, and the government has not been able to find funds to continue with that program for at least the foreseeable future. In relation to the R&D Start program, the government has frozen all applications for an indefinite period. In a statement straight out of George Orwell's Ministry of Truth in the book Nineteen Eighty-Four, the minister has said that there is no freeze, it is just that the government is processing no more applications for the foreseeable future. In fact it has instructed 115 small businesses to withdraw applications under the R&D Start program in order that the government not be embarrassed by the large number of applications that will not be processed as a result of this freeze.

Returning to the bill at large, the purpose of this legislation is essentially to make it easier for space launch activities in relation to a proposal at Christmas Island. My assessment of the market is that it is a highly competitive one and therefore there must be some question as to whether those activities will in the end be commercially viable. But the government has certainly received representations from the company and, as a result of those representations, has made the legislative and regulatory framework more conducive to those particular activities. That is something that we do not oppose but I do need to express some reservations about the commercial viability. Ultimately, that will be tested in the marketplace. I do not think the government needs to do any more in relation to that than it already has.
I turn now to the second reading amendment, which has been circulated, and move:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

speech.para: âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House

(1) noting that the issue of insurance is a central part of the Government's proposal, expresses concerns about the Government's priorities in offering $3 billion of insurance cover for space launching when school fetes, country shows and sporting associations are struggling to meet the exorbitant cost of public liability insurance; and
(2) notes that the Government has been able to find $100 million to support the Asia Pacific Space Centre while freezing the R&D Start Program.

I think it is time that the government did resolve this very pressing issue of public liability insurance in relation to school fetes, sporting associations and country shows. It has been going on long enough, and I think every member of parliament would have examples from their own areas of these small community organisations either not being able to proceed with their activities this year or, if they are able to proceed, facing much higher costsâmany multiples of the costs that they faced in previous years. Any profits in relation to these activities that are ploughed back into schools, sporting associations and the like will therefore be greatly diminished. The government has been messing around on this for a considerable time. It does not seem to have been able to reach any agreement with the states. As a result of that, we find these small organisations in a very difficult situation; yet, on the other hand, the government says that it is not a problem for it to provide insurance cover amounting to $3 billion in relation to the launch site on Christmas Island. As I say, it is a strange set of priorities that the government has.

I now move on to this further concern about the priorities that the government have, and that is that they have managed to find a full $100 million in support of this program through the Strategic Investment Coordination Program but have frozen the R&D Start program. I want to draw the attention of the House to the impact of these sorts of decisions. It is an impact that is already predicted in the budget papers. It is well known that, since the government came into office in 1996, research and development as a share of GDP has declined in each and every year. That is a very bad portent for Australia's economic future because obviously innovation is a key driver of growth in this so-called `global knowledge economy', yet the government are saying, `Look, we have already done enough on innovation.' In fact, the minister made that very statement just a few months ago, on 29 January, in the Australian Financial Review when he said:

quote.para: Sure we'd love to do more, we'd love to spend more money ... but we've got the balance pretty right for R & D.

speech.para: If the balance for R&D is `pretty right', the minister's definition of `right' is that R&D spending by the private sector as a proportion of GDP has fallen in each and every year of the Howard governmentâand he says that that is `pretty right'! To make matters worse, the rest of the world is not standing still. The OECD is spending an increasing proportion, on average, of GDP on R&D investment, while Australia each and every year is spending a declining proportion. How is the government responding to that? By cutting the R&D Start program.

The government, as I say, has in fact predicted quite clearly the impact of such decisionsâof its neglect of research and development and innovation in this country, including this decision to freeze the R&D Start program. I referred to the Intergenerat-ional Report, budget paper No. 5, that was included in the most recent budget, the day before yesterday. I have to advise the House that I think one of the most astonishing admissions that this government has ever madeâit does not make too many, but it has made an astonishing admission hereâhas gone essentially unnoticed and unreported. What the government is saying is that productivity growth by the middle of this decade will slump back to the mediocre levels of the last 30 years. The report says:

quote.para: Over the next four decades, economic growth is projected to slow relative to the outcomes achieved over the past decade, reflecting lower productivity and employment growth rates. Productivity growth is assumed to return to around its 30-year average, below the growth of the 1990s.

speech.para: It further says:

quote.para: Productivity growth indicates a higher level of output for a given level of inputs and will be the key driver of GDP growth in the decades ahead. Faster productivity growth would enable higher rates of growth of both GDP and real wages over the projection period, other factors unchanged.
... productivity is projected to grow at its long-term average rate (30 years) of about 1.75 per cent from the middle of this decade to the end of the projection horizonâ

speech.para: which is 40 years out. So the government is saying that it is content with its forecast that Australian productivity growth by the middle of this decadeâjust three years awayâwill slump back to the mediocre 30-year average. The government has had a lot to say about the importance of productivity growth, and I agree with the government on that. I will give some examples of what has been said. For example, on 8 December 1999, the Treasurer said:

quote.para: We have had high productivity and, along with the government's reform agenda, this will drive Australia into the next decade.

speech.para: The Prime Minister, talking about a `better than golden age' productivity growth, said that this `must be duplicated in future if we are to maintain the great improvement in the Australian economy'.
There are a range of other statements by both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer pointing to the importance of ongoing productivity growth. On 9 October 2000, the Prime Minister said:

quote.para: ... the measurement of whether an economy is in the current language `old' or `new' is, in my view, overwhelmingly determined by the capacity of an economy to use the benefits of technology, particularly information technology.
One of the reasons ... that over the last four years we have been able to increase the real incomes of Australian workers is that productivity has gone up.

speech.para: So there is the Prime Minister again pointing to the importance of productivity growth. The Treasurer on 18 February this year here in the parliament said:

quote.para: ... productivity is very important to the growth of the Australian economy. One of the reasons why the Australian economy has done comparatively well over the course of the 1990s, particularly over the last five years, is the strength in productivity growth ...

talk.start.para: âHear, hear!

âI am glad that the parliamentary secretary agrees, because I agree with him, and I agree with the Treasurer and with the Prime Minister, that productivity growth is very important. Again, the Treasurer said:

quote.para: Because productivity has been increasing, wage levels have been increasing under a coalition government ... We think that if you have increasing productivity, living standards can increase, and if you have good economic management you will have better productivity.

speech.para: Again, I think that is true. He said that on 8 February last year in the parliament. On 10 October 2000, the Treasurer said:

quote.para: It is important that we continue, that we take every step we can to enhance productivity in this country ...

speech.para: I am sure the parliamentary secretary would agree with that. I am sure everyone in this parliament would agree with it. But what is the result of the government's own Intergenerational Report? Is the government investing in the drivers of future economic growth, of future productivity growth and then enhanced future economic growth in this country? No, because it says that productivity growth will slump back to Australia's mediocre levels of the last 30 years. This is a startling admission, and I am astonished that the media has taken no interest in this whatsoever, because many people in the press gallery were around right through the Hawke-Keating period. You might recall some of Paul Keating's famous statements about the galah in the pet shop, squawking about micro-economic reform. Labor not only squawked about micro-economic reform but implemented micro-economic reform right through the period of the Hawke and Keating governments. We can start with the floating of the Australian dollar, with the liberalisation of financial markets. We go through to the tariff reducing programs in relation to whitegoods, automobiles and obviously textiles, clothing and footwear. All of these and more were important micro-economic reforms, and as a result of those major investments in the country's future, the dividends started flowing in the early 1990s in the form of a doubling of Australia's productivity growth. The Treasury and the Productivity Commission in fact have attributed the surge in Australian productivity growth to those very micro-economic reforms initiated by Labor.

Now, when we come to a crucial new point in our history where there is evidence already of productivity tapering off, we are in a situation where the government in its budget has said: `We are doing nothing more on this. We are investing no further in Australia's economic future. We are investing no further in the drivers of productivity and hence in the drivers of economic growth andâit followsâin the drivers of improved living standards for Australians.' This is a startling admission by this government that it is not investing any more in education. I understand the total new spending on education is $12 million. It is certainly not investing any more in innovation when it freezes the R&D Start program.

So where are we in Australia's history? We had this surge in productivity growth right through the 1990s. The Treasurer, when the Prime Minister was on his feet one day here the parliament lauding this golden age surge in productivity, advised the Prime Minister that in fact it was faster than the United Statesâand it was, and it is a good achievement on Australia's part to have achieved those massive increases and sustained increases in productivity. But the government has saidâthe Prime Minister has said this in the parliamentâthat it is good enough from now on to rely on Australia's capacity effectively to absorb technologies basically invented and developed in the United States and other Western countries. He is on the record as saying that, and I will repeat it:

quote.para: ... the measurement of whether an economy is in the current language `old' or `new' is, in my view, overwhelmingly determined by the capacity of an economy to use the benefits of technology, particularly information technology.

speech.para: That was on 9 October 2000. So he is saying that it is based on the capacity of an economy to use technologyâto absorb and use itâthat is, the Internet, personal computers and so on. The government in an incredibly complacent state of mind has said: `Well, we've got all of these inventions being done by Microsoft and other big businesses in the United States. Just as long as we absorb those enabling technologies, we're fine. We don't need to invest in the country's future; we'll just get Australians doing what they do best and that's absorbing and using overseas technologies.' The consequence of that is here for all to see: the government is saying, `We've done enough; we've racked the cue on economic reform; we've racked the cue in terms of investing in innovation, investing in education. We've done enough and we are now happy to forecast that productivity growth will slump to its 30-year average by the middle of this decade.' What an admission! That means that the economy will slow downâand that is also contained in the Intergenerational Reportâand the growth of living standards in Australia will slow down, and the government will not do anything about it.

I know what the government's response to what I have had to say will be, and that is: `Oh, this is just a series of projections. It is not necessarily what is going to happen.' I have two responses to that: it is what is going to happen, because nothing has been going on in terms of further investment in research and development and in education in this country and, secondly, if the government is arguing that it is just a series of projections, why did it put the lower productivity growth figureâthat is, reverting to the mediocre 30-year averageâinto the Intergenerational Report? The answer to that question would be that, if it is only an assumption, it put those figures in in order to produce less optimistic forecasts in terms of Australia's economic growth and as a consequence of the budget situation. In the Intergenerational Report the government says that, if nothing is done in terms of budget pruning of expenditure, there will be a deficit in 40 years time equal to five per cent of GDP, and that deficit works out at $87 billion in today's terms. So the government is ringing the alarm bells saying, `This is what we genuinely forecast is going to happen,' and quite clearly in the Intergenerational Report then says, `That is the reason we are making cuts to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.'

You cannot have it both ways. The government cannot say that this is just a set of projections that are not really going to happen, when those projections provide the justification for the announced cuts in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. You cannot say that. The projections also provide the justification for the cuts in the disability support pension. The government says that we have got to get into a budget repair mode now to stop the emergence of a fiscal deficit of five per cent of GDP, or $87 billion in today's terms, by putting in that productivity growth figure. The truth is that that is a reasonable forecast of what is going to happen to productivity growth in this country. It is a reasonable forecast because it is based on the fact that since its election the Howard government has cut government investment in research and development and in education.

As a consequence of that we have a crisis in our universities. We still have alarmingly low high school retention rates and we have had, in each and every year of the Howard government, a decline in business expenditure on research and development as a share of gross domestic product. It follows that if the government has racked the cue in terms of these investments in the nation's future then the key driver, productivity growth, will slump. So it is not just a projection; it is a realistic assessment, an admission by this government of what is going to happen as a result of its wilful neglect of investment in the nation's future.

There is the contrast. On the one hand Labor, through its agenda and commitment to additional investment in innovation, research and development and education, has an economic reform agenda for the future. The government's economic reform agenda does not exist. All it has is the sort of legislation that was put through this House of Representatives a while ago: further changes to the industrial relations system, which it says will have some impact on productivity. Those changes are simply an attack on Australian workers. They have nothing to do with lifting productivity in this countryâbecause the future of this country is as a high skill, high wage country. How do we become a high skill country? By investing in education and trainingâtwo areas where the government has said that enough has been done and the states can do the rest through the so-called growth tax in the GST. I believe that at present none of the states have actually benefited in net terms from the GST at all.

We are at a crucial point in Australian history. I do not think anyone would be proud to be around in this place in another six or eight years time where a leader of the country has to say, `Whoops! We got it wrong again.' Just as it was folly for Australia's future economic growth for us to rely for too long on Australia being a farm and a quarry, just so is it true today that it would be folly to rely on Australia being able to absorb and use overseas technologies. We do not have time up our sleeves. This is the time when those vital investments in the nation's future must be made, yet the government has no third-term agenda with regard to ongoing economic reform. All it wants to do is make some industrial relations changes, which are not designed to take Australia to the high road of a high skill, high wage country producing high value manufactured goods and services for the export market but are designed to compete globally on wage costs and to take the low road of low wages.

When that happens, when Australian businesses get in the situation where they are not innovating anymore and when the product becomes standardised, then the forces will come to bear for the production of that product to go overseas in search of lower labour costs and a larger scale. We will always be under pressure in this country by taking the low road, by taking the road that the government is taking now. This is the time to take the high road to a high skill, high wage economyâan economy for the future built on innovation, skills and a highly educated work force. But the government is not doing that. The government knows that that is the only decent and proper economic agenda for this country. Instead of doing that, it is embarking on a series of industrial relations changes designed to do nothing more than remove the remaining rights of workers in this country. That is taking us to the low road.

I hate to be so pessimistic, but I have to be, because that is where the government is taking us. I looked at the budget documents in the lock-up the night before last and, 3Â½ years after the government announced the great innovation of Backing Australia's Ability, I would ask this House: how much of the money allocated to that will have been spent 3Â½ years after that announcement? The answer is less than 20 per cent. So it was all fanfare and fairy floss: when it comes to actually spending the money, less than 20 per cent will have been spent 3Â½ years after that announcement at the beginning of the year 2000.

Further than that, industry department fundingâone of the key departments that should be driving the new economic agenda of investing in research and development and innovationâis forecast to fall by more than 30 per cent over the next four years. It will not even stay steady but will fall by more than 30 per cent. That is the largest fall for any spending department in the Commonwealth government.

talk.start.para: âYou love spending money, don't you, Craig? Spend, spend, spend!

âIt is not a question of spending money in this case in relation to the industry department; it is trying to justify a 30 per cent reduction in spending. And wait for it! Staffing is being cut by more than 10 per cent. How could anyone justify a 30 per cent cut in spending by the industry department and a 10 per cent cut in staffing? That is the set of priorities. No wonder the minister is named Chainsaw. He makes Al Dunlap look like a teddy bear. Old Chainsaw Dunlap would come in here and look like a teddy bear. This minister has only been in the portfolio for a few months: a 30 per cent cut in departmental funding, 10 per cent in staffing and no plan for this country's future.
(Mr Lindsay)âIs the amendment seconded?

â Whilst the Space Activities Amendment Bill 2002 before the House cannot be described as one giant leap for mankind, it is nonetheless more than a small step for a government. In the world bid for space relevance, this bill, which contains a new framework for space activities, is a significant advance. I wish to speak on four aspects of this legislation: firstly, the international obligations that it contains; secondly, certain language and textual changes that have been brought about by the act; thirdly, an insurance issue; and, fourthly, aspects of the regulatory framework. Finally, I will make some remarks about the commercial imperative behind the bill.

speech.para: The international framework, or the UN space agencies convention, which is correctly described as the Agreement Governing the Activities of States on the Moon and other Celestial Bodies, is at schedule 4 to the bill. It is a most interesting convention. As a member of the treaties committee, I took some interest in examining its terms. I note that the text of the convention itself has required some variation because of the number of problems in the drafting and textual infelicities when the convention was first put forward. The UN has conceded that there are some problems with this convention. It has brought it back, and that is one of the reasons that it has been annexed to this bill. The convention deals with the question of sovereignty in relation to the moon and other celestial bodies within our solar system in a way which is a very important guide to future space activities, should they ever lead to any commercial or other, even leisure, activities. Article 3 prescribes:

quote.para: 1. The moon shall be used by all States Parties exclusively for peaceful purposes.
2. Any threat or use of force or any other hostile act or threat of hostile act on the moon is prohibited.
4. The establishment of military bases, installations and fortifications, the testing of any type of weapons and the conduct of military manoeuvres on the moon shall be forbidden.

speech.para: The interesting aspect of this is that the hopes of those who were first involved in space and in the exploration of space appear to have been given some support in the wording of the convention. L.B.J., President Johnson, on 29 August 1965 in Johnson City, Texas, on the eve of an important US satellite launch, said: `No national sovereignty rules in outer space and those who venture there go as envoys of the entire human race. Their quest, therefore, must be for all mankind and what they should find belongs to all mankind.' This convention does encapsulate the spirit of those who first launched satellitesâboth the United States and the then Soviet Unionâand others since that time.

Another important topic dealt with by the convention includes exploration activities on the surface of the moon and other bodies within the solar system. Again, the prescription is of a general beneficial kind, and article 4 states:

quote.para: 1. The exploration and use of the moon shall be the province of all mankind and shall be carried out for the benefit and in the interests of all countries, irrespective of their degree of economic or scientific development.

speech.para: There are similar provisions for informing the Secretary-General of the United Nations, as well as the public and the international scientific community, of an intention to explore and to use the moon as soon as possible after launching any mission and for informing the Secretary-General of any phenomenon discovered in outer space. There is also a principle of freedom of scientific investigation on the moon.

Coupled with that is an important provision providing for measures to ensure that there is no disruption of the existing balance of the environment on the moon. It is called, rather oddly, `extra environmental contamination'. Those provisions, the detail of which I will not go into now, provide for a regime which Iâand, I suggest, all those who are interested in this topicâbelieve establishes a sound basis for exploration activities, if and when they become relevant, as we hope they will in the near future. Also, the more difficult topic of mining and utilisation of the surface of the moon is dealt with in article 8 and in following articles. A provision in article 8 states:

quote.para: 1. States Parties may pursue their activities in the exploration and use of the moon anywhere on or below its surface, subject to the provisions of this Agreement.

speech.para: Article 9 says:

quote.para: 1. States Parties may establish manned and unmanned stations on the moon.

speech.para: That is for the purpose of insuring that the natural resources on the moon are able to be exploited. Interestingly enough, in article 11, there is a general provision consistent with the nostrum that I mentioned earlier. It says that the moon and its natural resources are the common heritage of mankind and are not subject to national appropriation. Normal rules as to ownership have no relevance. It will be interesting in due course, once activities on the moon lead to actual exploitation through mining activities, to see precisely how any advantage is to be obtained. The convention does contemplate that an international regime at that time will be established, but at this stage that has not occurredâfor obvious reasons.

The final aspect of the convention that I will mention is most interesting and reflects back on L.B.J.'s comment that I mentioned earlier. It deals with the control of personnel and structures on the moon. Article 12 says that state parties shall retain jurisdiction and control over their personnel, but article 15 says that all space vehicles, equipment, facilities, stations and installations shall be open to other states parties, subject to advance notice. The concept of sharing and of the moon and other celestial bodies being part of the natural heritage of mankind is very much built into this convention, which is at schedule 4 of the bill.

The second aspect that I wish to address concerns some aspects of the language and textual comments contained in the bill. One of those is the definition that is given to the terms `launch' and `outer space'. For the first time `outer space' is clarified as being `an area beyond the distance of 100 kilometres above mean sea level'. For those of us who have enjoyed, and perhaps still enjoy, a somewhat poetic bent, this idea of closely defining `outer space' and where it starts and ends is of some amusement. Nonetheless, this bill does clarify what was a problem in the earlier legislation. It does mean that once one goes beyond 100 kilometres above mean sea level there will be an automatic operation of the bill. Consequently, `launch vehicles', `return' from outer space to the earth's atmosphere and `space objects' are defined in like manner. I think it was English astronomer and author Fred Hoyle who said in his book on the nature of the universe that space is not remote: it is only an hour's drive away if your car could go straight upwards. It seems to me, having regard to the definition that is written into this bill, that is probably about right.

The second textual aspect of the bill that I want to mention concerns the incorporation of section 51(xx) of the Constitution. In item 8 of the bill it is provided that any space applicant must be a corporation to which the Constitution applies. For my part, I would like to see, in due course, an agreement between all the states over the ceding of power to the Commonwealth to ensure that, whether the body involved in space activities is a corporation or an individual, the Commonwealth has proper jurisdiction over those activitiesâbecause, in the world of insurance and corporate veils, there is a certain guarantee in having individuals being involved and personally responsible for those activities. Perhaps that will occur in due course, and I hope it does.

The third matter that I want to mention concerns insurance. This bill does deal with a number of important aspects of the insurance regime in ways which I believe are very beneficial. We heard some comment from the Labor Party a little earlier about that but I suggestâhaving regard to the detailed provisions of this billâthat at the end of the day those concerns are amply met. Under the act, before a launch company will be allowed to conduct any launch activity, the company must either obtain insurance or demonstrate the financial capacity to self-insureâknown in the statute as `direct financial responsibility'.

The act currently requires that a company obtain insurance for damage to third parties up to an amount known as the `maximum probable loss'. The insurance required is calculated according to a methodology which estimates the maximum casualty or damages that might occur within the probability threshold. That threshold is where the probability is less than one chance in 10 million. The new measures proposed will cap the company's liability and therefore the level of insurance it is required to hold. It is expected that the new measures will therefore enable companies to obtain sufficient insurance to cover their liabilities and ensure that the insurance is available at rates consistent with commercially viable launch operations.

The amount of insurance required under this proposed legislation is capped at $750 million or a probability threshold, which may be less. That is, if the probability threshold worked out in accordance with the methodology I have mentioned is lower than $750 million, that will be the cap per launch. This amount is to be indexed in accordance with an agreement between the Minister for Finance and Administration and the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources and will be specified in the regulations.

In addition to the new cap on liability, the Commonwealth has agreed to accept liability for damage to the assets of Australian nationals up to an amount of $3 billion over and above the insured amount. Because of the rigour of the assessment procedures under the act and the MPL threshold, which I have just mentioned, there is only a remote risk that the Commonwealth will actually be called to account on this liabilityâalthough I want to say something a little more about the detail of the legislation on that in a moment. It is also important to note that Australia is a party to various UN conventionsâand I mentioned a little earlier that attached to this billâwhich place unlimited liability on the Commonwealth for any damage to foreign nationals caused by Australian launch activities. The new measures in respect of liability extend equivalent protection to Australian nationals but limit it to $3 billion and entrench this protection in domestic law. It is interesting to note that the proposed limit has been benchmarked against and is of a similar magnitude to the US arrangements, where the United States government accepts liability to a limit of $US1.5 billion.

The two provisions in relation to insurance that I wish to draw attention to are items 31 and 53. Item 31 deals with the cap of $750 million to which I referred a little earlier, and the question of general principle is whether or not the imposing of a cap on third-party liability insurance is the right way to go. Of course, it must be remembered, in considering this question, that the act imposes obligations on the launch activity owners to ensure not only their own obligations but the obligations of the Commonwealth. One way of dealing with it would be to exclude all common law rights altogether. The alternativeâand the measure proposed hereâis to place a cap on those liabilities. It is anticipatedâor it was anticipated, as I read the second reading speechâthat insurance would be available at about one per cent. I hope that that is the case and I do hope therefore that the minister and the department will keep under consideration and monitor the cost of insurance as against the ability and the capacity of those involved in space activities to undertake them.
The second issue I want to mention is the $3 billion cap which is contained in item 53. That item provides:

quote.para: (a) the responsible party has paid compensation for the damage of an amount equal to the insured amount ...

speech.para: It goes on to speak about that amountâI have already made mention of thatâand then says that, for an excess amount over and above the insured amount:
then the Commonwealth is liable to pay compensation to the Australian nationals for the damage of an amount equal to so much of the excess amount as does not exceed $3 billion.

One of the concerns that I haveâand which in due course should be monitored and perhaps given consideration to once this regime comes into effectâis whether or not that cap relates to any one incident and whether or not the Commonwealth might be exposing itself to a notional liability in excess of $3 billion in the event that, in relation to an incident, there is more than one claimant with a claim in excess of $3 billion. I suspect it would certainly be argued by those who have such claims that that would be the case, in which case I suspect it would be important from the taxpayer's point of view that that issue be clarified. It is not difficult to imagine, for example, a launch that might damage oil facilities in the Timor Sea or elsewhere where exposure to large amounts are involved. One of the aspects of the bill that might be worth monitoring is the question of the operation of that provision.

I turn finally to the issue of regulatory processes. The bill provides for operators to stipulate flight path plans; it establishes a launch safety officer; it gives certain powers to the launch safety officer to ensure that those that might be affected by the pathway are made safe; and it gives powers with criminal penalties to the launch safety officer to ensure that the launch is as safe as possible to Australians. It also provides for space licences, launch permits and overseas launch certificates to be amended in accordance with new powers to be given to the minister and for a fee structure to be established.

One of the issues that I suggest may arise for comment in due courseâand, again, this is something that may be monitored by the departmentâis the question of the number of government agencies involved in a space launch, so as to ensure that that be kept to a minimum and that there is no excessive red tape. At present, aspiring launch companies must deal with state and local governments, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, Environment Australia, Emergency Management Australia and other government agencies responsible for space launches. Of course, we have the Space Licensing and Safety Office, which is within the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources. In the United States, a similar office operates within the Civil Aviation Authority, and there may be some merit in giving consideration to those administrative arrangements.

The commercial benefits from this legislation are significant. There are at present some three operators that are examining carefully the possibility of launching space activities from Australia. One of those, the Asia Pacific Space Centre at Christmas Island, is well advanced. That organisation has been assisted by a significant investment from Invest Australia. I commend, in those circumstances, this bill to the House and the program which the government has put forward. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI listened with interest to the contribution made in this debate by the honourable member for Wentworth. It was certainly a well constructed and well thought out contribution. I have not had the opportunity of hearing the honourable member for Wentworth in this place debating these issues before. It is not an area that perhaps is a native one to a lot of members in this chamber. I found his comments on the issue of the regulatory arrangements quite interesting. There are a lot of regulatory agencies that are involved in this issue of space launches, and I think it is a worthwhile suggestion that he makes that perhaps we ought to look at a structure within government that rationalises to some degree the processes by which companies approach government and get their particular proposal considered.

speech.para: The agencies that he mentioned are, of course, very important agencies. However, that is not to say that, in this potentially very important new area of economic activity for Australia, we cannot do better in getting a better set of regulatory arrangements. Having said that, I think there is a legitimate criticism of the government in the way that it has handled the Asia Pacific Space Centre proposal. It is a carbon copy of how things ought not to be done, and I will be speaking a little more about it later on in this debate.

The Space Activities Amendment Bill 2002 is an extension of the original Space Activities Act 1998, which established the legislative framework for space launches conducted in Australia and for overseas launches where Australians have an ownership interest. The amendment bill is necessary for the ongoing development of the legislative framework that surrounds the launching of space vehicles in this country. The major amendments made by the bill have already been canvassed in this debate. They are: the legislation caps at $750 million the amount of insurance required to be procured by proponents for each launch, and it provides for the Commonwealth to accept liability for third-party Australian nationals above the insured amount for up to $3 billion. It has already been noted that the Commonwealth is already liable for damages to foreign third parties under United Nations conventionsâan issue which was canvassed in detail by the previous speaker in this debate.

Another amendment in this bill tightens the safety test being applied to commercial applicants for instruments by making provision for a test of risk that is `as low as is reasonably practicable' instead of `sufficiently low', as is the current case. The bill also provides for a less onerous application and assessment process and for lower fee regimes for scientific and educational organisations.

All people in this House, especially those of my vintage, have quite a strong fascination for things related to space. We have probably all sat outside on a moonlit nightâ I was always by myself of courseâgazing into the southern skies and outer space and wondering whether there is life out there. I have often gazed at the other place and asked that very question in this parliament! We have all had this strange fascination with space. I grew up in the sixtiesâas did many honourable members hereâand witnessed the first satellite launch and man's quest to walk on the moon. We did not have a television in the early days of my upbringing, but later on when we did acquire one I became a fan of Star Trek, with Captain Kirk and the good ship Enterprise boldly going where no man has gone before. That famous line from Star Trek reminds me of what it would be like tuning in to an agenda session of the Howard cabinet: `Beam me up, Scottyâ there's no sign of life down here.'

Space has also been immortalised in song. Of course, we know the propensity of honourable Parliamentary Secretary Entsch to burst into song in the oddest of places: `Fly me to the moon and let me play among the stars; let me see what spring is like on Jupiter and Mars'âI think it goes something like that. I think we all have a very strong fascination for matters relating to mankind's quest to go to the stars.

I would like to recall for the House an incident that occurred to me in the early stages of my tenure as the member for Corio. As honourable members would know, the election of a new member always brings out the maddies in your electorate, the people who have tried it on with the previous member. That member has retired, so they try it on with the new member. I can recall the day I was visited by a young man from the northern area of my electorate. Beside the note in the diary where my staff booked him in was the notation `Wants to talk about space launches'. I thought, `Well, here we go! This'll be an interesting one.' I was absolutely fascinated because in came the 17-year-old son of a worker from the northern suburbs. Anybody who knows the physical aspects of my electorate would know that in the seat of Corio is Avalon Airport, which was owned by the federal government and was sold by the coalition to Lindsay Fox. It is a military airfield and it will take the heaviest airfreighters known to man, from the United States and the former Soviet Union.

I note the presence in this House of the member for Corangamite, who on many occasions, I am sure, has been into outer space. Some of his contributions to the debate in this chamber would certainly indicate that fact. We do not know whether it was a case of somebody going up into outer space or coming down from outer space when he made those contributions on industrial relations! But I do acknowledge the member from the other side of the Barwon River in the Geelong region, and he would know what I am talking about here.

To continue: this young man, a 17-year-old, came in and I sat in all seriousness and listened to his proposal to establish a low orbital satellite launch site at Avalon Airport in Geelong. It was fascinating listening to this young man. He was very knowledgable in a technical sense and he had done a lot of reading. He considered this to be an economic opportunity to pursue. I cannot remember his name, but in 1993 this young man was obviously ahead of his time as far as Australia's involvement in these activities was concerned.

The honourable member in the previous debate mentioned the current proposal to build a satellite launch facility on Christmas Island. This project is being sponsored by the Asia Pacific Space Centre. It is a very interesting proposal and one of substantial costâ some $800 million, with $100 million being committed by the federal government. The estimates of demand 10 years out for the product of this sort of launch facility is around $40 billion. Estimates have been provided that Australia has the potential to win some 10 per cent to 20 per cent of that market. At the moment, the market is dominated by the United States, Russia, the European Union and by China.

The proponents of this project have selected Australia for some obvious reasons. We are a country with considerable economic and technical capacity and a nation which is politically stable; but I suppose it is the location that has largely attracted this proposal. Our sub-equatorial location is very favourable for such vehicles because it enables them to be launched with large payloads. This proposal offers considerable opportunities for Australia in the design and manufacture of satellites and in the development of communications technology and will provide $15 million for a space research centre that will link in with educational institutions. The jobs projected to be created in the construction phase are 300 to 400, and about 550 jobs when the facility is operational. It will, of course, provide significant stimulus to the air links between Christmas Island, Australia and other parts of Asia.

It is a very important project and one that is worthy of real examination and debate by this parliament. There are particular concerns about this proposal, and I raise them in the context of this debate. I do not raise them in the sense of arguing against the proposal but to alert the parliament to the fact that there are significant environmental concerns with the APSC proposal, especially as it relates to the provision of water supply and the effect of noise on endangered species on the island, which is covered, in the main, by national parks. Very legitimate concerns have been expressed, and it is disappointing that despite the proposal and the ordinance having been introduced here and despite the expenditure that the federal government is makingâ some $100 millionâthe government has sought to exclude this proposal from proper parliamentary processes and parliamentary scrutiny.

The government does not have to do it this way; there is another way to engage the community when handling these large projects. At the end of the day, if the government does not pursue another way of dealing with the process and the important issues, it will make it extremely difficult for the parliament to deliver the sort of support that could be forthcoming for such a project and it will make it hard for the proponents of the proposal. It is frustrating for them to eternally have to face conflicts and problems that could have been avoided if the matter had been dealt with in another way.

I refer to a letter I received from the Shire of Christmas Island. The authors of the letter alerted me to their concerns about the `Christmas Island Space Centre (APSC Proposal) Ordinance 2001' and its accompanying regulations. They also sent me a copy of a letter they wrote to the Hon. Wilson Tuckey, the Minister for Territories and Regional Services, whom I shadow in this parliament. The letter makes disturbing reading for a variety of reasons. The shire has expressed some real concerns at the level of consultation on this proposal that has taken place between the federal government and the small Christmas Island community. I commend the shire for the forensic analysis that they have provided of the ordinance. They have raised some very serious matters relating to the conduct of public policy and to the legal and technical ramifications of the ordinance that the government has brought into the parliament.

Their first concern relates to the consultation that took place between the government and the shire and the community over this ordinance. Apparently, there was no consultation in the drafting phase and no notification of the gazettal of the ordinance. This is simply not good enough. I do not care whether it is a small community or a large community, whether it is a big project or a small project, the processes of the national government ought to be inclusive. They ought to include the community in proper consultation and dialogue on the potential problems that might arise either from government legislation that comes before this House or from ordinances and regulations that are promulgated as a result of the activities of this parliament.

It must be very disappointing for APSC, who have spent a lot of time and money on the project, to be part of any unprofessionalâand some might say quite amateurishâpublic policy process. I remind the parliament and the minister of the current make-up of the parliament and the fact that we as an opposition are committed to the pursuit of good public policy processes and good government.

I note that, following the substantial representations that have been made about the ordinance and the regulations, a dialogue is currently occurring between the minister and the community on Christmas Island. I regret that it was not done beforehand by the previous minister who had carriage of thisâI suppose we cannot lump it all on the current ministerâor by the current minister. There is a dialogue taking place as a result of those representations, and we are going to listen to that dialogue very closely. If we determine that the minister is in good faith negotiating and is attempting to address the very real and considered concerns that have been expressed, then we will be supportive of the government's endeavours to get this proposal up. But we put on notice that there is an avenue available in the Senate for this ordinance to be withdrawn, and we will be listening to the dialogue and its outcome closely to ensure that good governance takes place around this particular proposal.
On the issue of consultation, the shire had this to say:

quote.para: In the shire's view, to make the APSC ordinance without any reference to the shire of the community for input, explanation or discussion goes against the spirit and intent of the Christmas Island Act 1958. The shire is also of the view that to not consult with the shire goes against the policy and spirit of the established means of consulting island residents about the application of laws to the territory.

speech.para: It is a small thing, but it is also a very important thing. Governments must consult with communities before they make substantial decisions on these sorts of projects. The shire has detailed very serious matters relating to the exclusion zone and the legal and technical problems that have arisen for them. They have raised serious equity issues about the cost of infrastructure on the island and the process for establishing independence and fairness in decision making about this satellite launch facility.

Let me say in conclusion that I am encouraged by the dialogue that is occurring between the minister and the Christmas Island community. speech.para: Australia's involvement with space activities goes back to the beginning of the space age itself. In the years following the Second World War, our participation in British missile programs catapulted us to the forefront of the international space program and made Central Australia home to one of the world's major spaceports. In November 1967, Australia became only the third nation, after the Soviet Union and the United States, to launch a satellite from its own soil. Despite our early pioneering role, Australia's space launch activity has been somewhat limited over the past two decades. For example, there have not been any rocket launches for commercial purposes from Australian soil.

However, the proposed construction of the Aurora rocket launch facility on Christmas Island has the potential to enhance Australia's prominence in the field of space launches. In light of this, the government is introducing necessary amendments to the existing legislative framework. The Space Activities Amendment Bill 2002 will do this by updating the Space Activities Act 1998 in three ways: the bill will strengthen the risk tests applying to the safety of launch activities, it will make specific provisions for scientific and educational organisations that will increase their opportunities to engage in space research and it will also introduce important measures that are necessary given the changing insurance and liability environment.

I would like to begin by discussing the amendments relating to the safety of launch facilities, before moving on to some other key amendments. At present, under the Space Activities Act the construction and operation of a launch facility is considered to have an acceptable level of risk if the probability that the facility will cause damage to property and/or substantial harm to public health and safety is deemed to be `sufficiently low'. This bill will apply a stronger risk test. It will amend the act by redefining the acceptable level of risk to `as low as reasonably practicable'. The amendment puts the onus on applicants for launch facility licences to demonstrate that they have achieved, within the bounds of reasonable cost, the lowest practicable risk outcomes. It will bring the regulatory philosophy of the act into line with best practice safety regulations.

Further measures that underline the bill's emphasis on safety include the extension of power to the minister to suspend a launch permit. Under the Space Activities Act, a launch permit is automatically suspended in the event of an accident causing physical harm or damage to property. However, while the minister currently has the power to suspend a launch permit for reasons relevant to Australia's national security or our international obligations, there is no provision in the act for the minister to suspend a launch permit in the event of a prescribed `incident'. Under section 86 of the Space Activities Act, an incident is defined as one which:

quote.para: ... affects or could affect the safety of the operation of the space object or that involves circumstances indicating that an accident nearly occurred.

speech.para: The bill will provide the minister with the power to suspend a launch permit in the event of such incidents. If, for example, a launch permit is issued for a series of launches and one of the launches results in an incident, this amendment will give the minister the power to suspend any subsequent launches allowed by the permit, and enable the minister to conduct an investigation. This process will enhance safety by identifying and rectifying launch practices that may result in property damage and/or serious injury or death. The bill's emphasis on safety is further reinforced by the requirement that applicants identify all of the proposed flight paths for rockets launched from a launch facility. This measure will enable the regulator, the Australian Space Licensing and Safety Office, to assess each of the proposed flight paths against the requirement of achieving a risk level that is as low as is reasonably practicable.

The second major component of the bill provides for an enhancement of the existing liability and insurance arrangements for space launches. Commercial space launch organisations have expressed their concern that an open-ended liability regime would result in prohibitive insurance costs or even lead them to being unable to procure insurance for launches at all. The bill addresses this problem by capping the liability of launch operators, in order to provide a greater level of certainty to their operations, as well as providing a key foundation to their commercial viability. Under the new measures outlined in the bill, those undertaking launch activities will be required to obtain insurance for each launch up to a maximum defined probable loss or $750 million, dependant upon which is the lower amount. Beyond this amount, the Commonwealth will accept third-party liabilities to Australian nationals for damage resulting from authorised launch activities. The Commonwealth's acceptance of liability above the insured amount will be capped at $3 billion. I do commend to the House the extensive comments made by the member for Wentworth on some of the implications of this and some of the international obligations we have assumed in terms of space exploration.

The bill's third major amendment relates to space launch applications made by approved scientific, educational or other non-profit organisations. As most of the launch activities undertaken by such organisations would not usually involve the establishment, management and ongoing operation of a major launch facility, they should not be subjected to the full force of the licensing regime. This bill will address this issue by providing for two things: first, a less burdensome application process than that imposed upon applicants for a commercial launch licence; and, second, an alternative fee structure. Application processes for approved scientific and educational organisations will be made less onerous, as they will not be required to provide the same levels of information that commercial applicants must. This will in turn impose a lesser burden on the regulator in assessing such applications. The significantly lower fees that will be imposed upon these organisations when applying for launch approval reflect the public good aspect of their activities as well as the typically small-scale nature of their activities, their streamlined licensing processes and the modest funding of their operations.

It is important to note that the decline in revenue from launch fees derived from scientific, educational and non-profit organisations will be offset by an additional measure outlined in the bill. Under the current terms set down by the act, the regulator may only charge a fee at the time an organisation applies for a launch licence. There is no provision that allows for any further fees to be derived from an issued licence. This bill contains a measure that will allow the Space Licensing and Safety Office to charge an annual fee to recover a greater amount of its costs incurred through each space licence. In conclusion, this bill will make a significant number of improvements to the safety aspect of space launch activities, and it will make important adjustments that will enhance the existing liability and insurance arrangements for space launches. I commend the bill to the House.

speech.para: All these proposals carry with them varying degrees of technical and financial risk. I am hopeful that one or more of them will ultimately be an operational and commercial success. It will certainly result in new opportunities for other parts of the space industry in Australia in satellite construction, remote sensing and communication. Those opportunities are ever widening, and I think that despite the current oversupply of commercial launches it is not too late for Australia to enter this market, particularly given our comparative advantages of geography, weather, political stability and the sophistication of Australia's related industry capabilities. It is my understanding that the current set of proponents are not seeking any special government subsidies to achieve their objectives. That has not always been the case. talk.start.para: âIf the government is such a good economic manager, why does it hit the sickest and the poorest with a 30 per cent increase in the cost of their essential medicinesâthree times the rate of the GST? It is unfair: it hits pensioners and concession cardholders and it hits families under financial pressure. This measure hits the sickest, the poorest and the oldest. It hits the sickest and the poorest hardest. It is unfair, it is unjust and it will be opposed by us in this place and in the Senate. The measure needs to be outlined to the House in detail so that the full scale of the government's attack on pensioners and families under financial pressure can be appreciated.

speech.para: The government's proposal means that families will now pay $28.60 for each prescriptionâup $6.20 per scriptâup to a total of $190 extra each year for their essential medicines. Pensioners and other cardholders will now pay $4.60 for each prescriptionâ up $1 per scriptâup to a total of $52 a year more for their essential medicines. What that means for at least one million pensioners and cardholders is that they will pay the maximum and be $52 a year worse off. What it means is that 300,000 Australians in families will pay the maximum $190 at the non-concessional rate. So it is a 30 per cent increase in the cost of essential medicinesâ three times the rate of the GST.

When you add these together with the cost of the increases to the co-payment that the government introduced in the 1996 budget, that is a rise of 70 per cent in the cost of essential medicines for pensioners, cardholders and families under financial pressure since this government came to office. When you look at the failure of the government to increase the pensioners pharmaceutical allowance, from 1 August this year pensioners will be $88.40 worse off each year compared to where they were in 1996. It is an unjust measure; it is unfair; it hits the sickest and the poorest and elderly people hardest. It hits families under financial pressure very hard indeed. Everyone knows that if you have more than one child generally children get sick together. Now the costs of scripts for families under financial pressure, if two children in the family are sick at the same time, will be effectively $60 and if three are sick at the same time it will be $90âa huge burden on families under financial pressure.

How do the Treasurer and the Prime Minister respond to such a burden on pensioners and families? On radio yesterday the Treasurer said that the `change for pensioners is one dollarâwe are not hitting pensioners'. So, as far as the Treasurer is concerned, he is so out of touch that he deems that a one dollar a week increaseâ$52 per yearâfor one million pensioners is not hitting pensioners. He also asserts that you do not hit Australian families under financial pressure. There are 300,000 Australians in families who will be hit by the maximum increase of about $190 per year.

The government's justification for such a massive increase in the cost of essential medicines is twofold: firstly, that steps are needed to maintain and sustain the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme; and, secondly, that steps are needed on the basis of the Intergenerational Report tabled with the budget. The truth is that this measure is no more nor no less than a measure designed to rescue the government's deficit. This is a measure which hits the sickest and the poorest hardest and it is designed simply to shore up Peter Costello's and John Howard's budget bottom line.

The reason they are embarking on this measure has nothing to do with health policy; it has everything to do with the fact that in the run-up to the election the government splurged a budget surplus. Three or four years ago, the Treasurer stood in this place and said that on Tuesday night the budget surplus would be $14.6 billion. However, in the run-up to the election, they were prepared to do anything, say anything, spend on anything to save their political skins and get themselves re-elected. It is one story on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme before the election and another story after. What is the truth? The truth is that this has nothing to do with the sustainability of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, it has nothing to do with the Intergenerational Report and it has everything to do with rescuing the government's deficit. They will slug the sickest and the poorest to do that.

Let me make some remarks about the sustainability of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. We heard nothing from the government in the run-up to the election that suggested that, to them, cost or sustainability of the scheme was an issue. In June 2000, the spokesperson for the former minister for health Michael Wooldridge said:

quote.para: It is simply not true to suggest that cost is the overriding factor.

speech.para: The former health minister himself, Dr Wooldridge, in this place on 7 February 2001, when asked about the increased cost of Celebrex, the arthritis drug, said:

quote.para: Had we taken the advice of the PBAC ... the drug would never have been listed. The fact that it is costing money means that many more consumers are benefiting from the drug.

speech.para: So there was no talk about the cost of the scheme before the election. I put to the Prime Minister today Dr Wooldridge's comments on the Meet the Press program in June last year, where Dr Wooldridge made the point that the growth in cost was, in the year he was referring to, about 13 per cent, and that that was sustainableâ$4.42 billion in a financial year and the scheme was still sustainable. So there were no worries about cost before, no worries about a lack of sustainability in the run-up to the election. On the contrary, what did the government do so far as the scheme was concerned? It listed Celebrex without cost controls against the recommendation of the expert committee, it listed Zyban and it botched the Treasurer's quarter billion dollar GST transition budget bungle. So when you look at the last financial yearâthe financial year in the run-up to the electionâwhat is the analysis? The analysis of the growth in the PBSâthe Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemeâover the last decade and the six or seven years on the government's watch is an average annual increase in the order of 10, 11 or 12 per cent. In the financial year in the year running up to the election, the cost was 20 per cent, and that was essentially coming from measures of the government's own making: the listing of Celebrex, the listing of Zyban, the loss to the budget because of the so-called quarter billion dollar Treasurer's budget bungle and the introduction by the government itself of more concession cardholders to the scheme. When you take out those factors, the most recent data we have available and from the industry suggests that this year we will be looking at an increase in the order of 12, 13 or 14 per cent.

With regard to the government's justification that the scheme is not sustainable, we had none of that before the election. With regard to the government's other justification that, in the last financial year, there was exponential growth, it is all of their own work and, on the most recent data available to us, this year it has gone back to the average annual increase. It is an entirely separate question as to whether, in the next 50 years, an average annual increase in the order of 10 per cent renders the scheme sustainable or not, but there is a whole range of things that you can do to address that which do not require whacking or slugging pensioners or whacking or slugging families under financial pressure for the cost of their essential medicines.

It is possible to ensure that over the next 50 years the hallmarks of the scheme for the last 50 years remain true. It is possible to have a scheme where Australian consumers get access to the best medicines at affordable prices and where we continue to have, because of the basis of the scheme, a vibrant pharmaceutical research and manufacturing industry in Australia.

When you look at the Intergenerational Report, the government has said that it is very important we make these changesâa small stepânow, that it is very important we whack pensioners and families under pressure now, because in 2040 we will have this terrible problem. The Prime Minister today, when I put to him the attitude of his health minister in the six months before the election, said, `Oh, poor old Michael. He didn't have access to the Intergenerational Report.' The problem for the Prime Minister and the Treasurer is that the Intergenerational Report is neither new nor surprising. It is no wonder, given the measures in this budget so far as pharmaceuticals and disability pensions are concerned, that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister would like to have you looking at the horizon while, in the case of pharmaceuticals, every time you turn up to a chemist to get a prescription for your kids, Peter Costello has got his hand in your pocket. The Intergenerational Report on page 1 says:

quote.para: ... if policies are not adjusted, the current generation of taxpayers is likely to impose a higher tax burden on the next generation. The required adjustment in taxes and spending is about 5.0 per cent of GDP by 2041-42 ...

speech.para: What a similar studies do we find or are we aware of? We know that in 1996 the government received the National Commission of Audit Report to the Commonwealth Government, which had a separate chapter dealing with this issue. We know that in 1998 the government was aware of the OECD report, Maintaining prosperity in an ageing society. We know that in 1999 there was the production of the National Strategy for an Ageing Australia. We know that in 2001 the OECD economics department did a working paper on fiscal implications for ageing, and we know that Australia is well placed, and better placed than most nations, to deal with this issue. So the issues raised by the Intergenerational Report, far from being hidden from the government in the last six months, are neither new nor surprising. Indeed, one of the key findings, in chapter 6 of the National Commission of Audit report, says this:

quote.para: Projections based on recent health cost trends and demographic change suggest public and private health expenditure will absorb 8.6 per cent more of GDP by the year 2041. Assuming that the current financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and the current level of private funding are maintained, this implies an increase in Commonwealth outlays of around 3.9 per cent of GDP, an increase of almost $19b against current GDP.

speech.para: They had a report of a comparable nature in their hands six years ago. Why is it such a problem now? It is such a problem now because the government needed a distraction to get people to focus on looking down the track rather than on this measure to rescue their budget bottom line.

There is a range of things that we can do to help ensure that the scheme remains sustainable in the long term. The Treasurer publiclyâin the House yesterday and overnight, for exampleâlikes to create the impression that our opposition to the increasing cost of the copayment, which will raise about $1.1 billion, also includes the $800 million worth of savings measures that the government announced in the budget. That is not the case. We support those measures at face value. We would like to have a look at the detail to ensure that the detail stacks up, but in general terms we are supportive of those measures. Why is that? Because those things do go to the long-term sustainability of the scheme. Indeed, in the last election we had a range of policies in this area, some of which the government have taken up in the budget, in whole or in part, and some of which they have not. Some of the suggestions that are in the budget papers include the use of generic drugs where appropriate, stopping pharmaceutical fraud, improving the listing process for new medicines, providing better information and guidance to prescribing doctors and increasing the focus on evidence based medicine. All these things are sensible; all these things we support.

We also suggested in the run-up to the last election and since then that, to avoid the difficulty the government got into so far as Zyban was concerned, where it cost the government an extra $70 million in the first five months, we have an increased focus on the cost and prescribing pattern of new drugs in the first year. We might want to think about including the full cost of the drug on the label of the medicines. We might want to think about tighter controls so far as direct consumer advertising is concerned and we can certainly look at greater scrutiny of industry marketing. These are sensible things that we can do to ensure the long-term sustainability of the scheme. It is possible to continue for the next 50 years what we have had for the last 50 years: a scheme configured by Chifley and implemented by Menzies where you have affordable drugs, the best and latest drugs available to Australians at affordable rates to the patient and the taxpayer; a scheme with which we will continue to haveâunlike, for example, New Zealandâa vibrant pharmaceutical research and manufacturing industry which is involved in research and development here, which produces drugs and which also engages in export.

But that is not what the government is on about. The government likes to use the Intergenerational Report as cover. It likes to use the sustainability of the scheme as cover. But what it is doing here has nothing to do with health; it has everything to do with crude cost-cutting measures. It has everything to do with the fact that, in the run-up to the election, the government would do anything, say anything, spend on anything to save its political skin. Now it will whack the sickest and the poorest, the weakest, the elderly and families under financial pressure. It will whack these people to rescue itself from a deficit of its own making, a deficit caused by a spending splurge when it would do anything, say anything to get itself re-elected. Now Australians who need affordable medicines for their children or for their sick parents are going to be whacked by three times the rate of the GST to cover its splurge. Even Peter Costello and John Howard accepted that a GST should not apply to medicines; now we find three times the rate of the GST applied to essential medicines, adding up to a 70 per cent increase in the cost of essential medicines for Australians since this government came to office. This is a brutal measure, and we will oppose it tooth and nail in this House and in the Senate.
